column13: Gross-Russland}} which literally means ''Little Russia'' and ''Great Russia'', respectively.]]

column5: \"In Little Russia\". Photo by [[Sergey Prokudin-Gorsky]], between 1905 and 1915.]]

column1: The first recorded usage of the term is attributed to [[Boleslaus George II of Halych]].<ref name=Rusyna274>Русина О. В. Україна під татарами і Литвою. – Київ: Видавничий дім «Альтернативи» (1998), {{ISBN
column2: 966-7217-56-6}} – с. 274.</ref> In a 1335 letter to [[Dietrich von Altenburg]], the [[Grand Master (order)
column3: Grand Master]] of the [[Teutonic Knights]], he [[Style (manner of address)
column4: styled]] himself «dux totius Rusiæ Minoris».<ref name=Rusyna274/> The name was used by [[Patriarch Callistus I of Constantinople]] in 1361 when he created two [[metropolitan bishop
column8: Vladimir]] and [[Kiev]] and Little Rus' with its centers in [[Halych
column9: Galich]] (''Halych'') and [[Novgorodok]] (''Navahrudak'').<ref name=Rusyna274/> King [[Casimir III of Poland]] was called \"the king of [[Lechia]] and Little Rus'.\"<ref name=Rusyna274/> According to [[Mykhaylo Hrushevsky]], Little Rus' was the [[Halych-Volhynia
column10: Halych-Volhynian Principality]], after the downfall of which the name ceased to be used.<ref name=Hrush>Грушевський М.С. Історія України-Руси, том I, К. 1994, \"Наукова думка\", с. 1–2. {{ISBN

column1: In the post-medieval period, the name ''Little Rus''' was first used by the [[Eastern Orthodox]] clergy of the [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]], e.g. by influential cleric and writer Ioan Vyshensky (1600, 1608), [[Michael_I_of_Kiev_(metropolitan)
column2: Metropolitan Matthew of Kiev and All Rus']] (1606), Bishop Ioann (Biretskoy) of [[Przemyśl
column4: Metropolitan Isaiah (Kopinsky)]] of Kiev, [[Archimandrite]] Zacharias Kopystensky<ref>[[:de:Zacharias Kopystenski]]</ref>{{Circular reference
column5: date=March 2019}} of [[Kiev Pechersk Lavra]], etc.<ref name=Rusyna276>Русина О. В. Україна під татарами і Литвою. – Київ: Видавничий дім «Альтернативи» (1998), {{ISBN
column6: 966-7217-56-6}} – с. 276.</ref> The term has been applied to all Orthodox [[Ruthenia
column7: Ruthenian]] lands of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.<ref name=Rusyna276/> Vyshensky addressed \"the Christians of Little Russia, brotherhoods of [[Lviv]] and [[Vilnius
column8: Vilna]],\" and Kopystensky wrote \"Little Russia, or Kiev and Lithuania.\"<ref name=Rusyna276/>

column1: The term was adopted in the 17th century by the [[Tsardom of Russia]] to refer to the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] of [[Left-bank Ukraine]], when the latter fell under Russian protection after the [[Treaty of Pereyaslav]] (1654). From 1654 to 1721, the official title of Russian [[Tsar
column2: tsars]] contained the language (literal translation) ''\"The Sovereign of all [[Etymology of Rus and derivatives

column1: The term ''Little Rus''' has been used in letters of the [[Hetmans of Ukrainian Cossacks
column2: Cossack Hetmans]] [[Bohdan Khmelnytsky]]<ref>«…Самой столицы Киева, також части сие Малые Руси нашия». \"Воссоединение Украины с Россией. Документы и материалы в трех томах\", т. III, изд-во АН СССР, М.-Л. 1953, № 147, {{LCCN
column3: 54028024}}, с. 257.</ref> and [[Ivan Sirko]].<ref name=Yavor26>Яворницкий Д.И. История запорожских казаков. Т.2. К.: Наукова думка, 1990. 660 с. {{ISBN
column8: date=2007-03-20 }}</ref><ref>\"Листи Івана Сірка\", изд. Института украинской археографии, К. 1995, с. 13 и 16.</ref> [[Innokentiy Gizel]], [[Archimandrite]] of the [[Kiev-Pechersk Lavra]], wrote that the Russian people were a union of three branches— Great Russia, Little Russia, and White Russia—under the sole legal authority of the [[Moscow]] Tsars. The term ''Little Russia'' has been used in Ukrainian chronicles by [[Samiilo Velychko]], in a chronicle of the [[Hieromonk]] Leontiy (Bobolinski), and in ''Thesaurus'' by Archimandrite Ioannikiy (Golyatovsky).<ref>https://sk.theglossypages.com/golyatovsky-ioannicius-95281</ref><ref name=Rusyna279>Русина О. В. Україна під татарами і Литвою. – Київ: Видавничий дім «Альтернативи», 1998. – с. 279.</ref>

column1: The usage of the name was later broadened to apply loosely to the parts of [[Right-bank Ukraine]] when it was annexed by Russia at the end of the 18th century upon the [[partitions of Poland]]. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the [[History of the administrative division of Russia
column2: Russian Imperial administrative units]] known as the [[Little Russia Governorate (1764–1781)
column3: Little Russian Governorate]] and eponymous [[General Governorship]] were formed and existed for several decades before being split and renamed in subsequent administrative reforms.

column1: Up to the very end of the 19th century, ''Little Russia'' was the prevailing term for much of the modern territory of Ukraine controlled by the [[Russian Empire]], as well as for its people and their language. This can be seen from its usage in numerous scholarly, literary and artistic works. [[Ukrainophilia
column2: Ukrainophile]] historians [[Mykhaylo Maksymovych]], [[Nikolay Kostomarov]], Dmytro Bahaliy, and [[Volodymyr Antonovych]] acknowledged the fact that during the Russo-Polish wars, ''Ukraine'' had only a geographical meaning, referring to the borderlands of both states, but ''Little Russia'' was the [[ethnonym]] of Little (Southern) Russian people.<ref name=Khrapachevsky>In his private diary Taras Shevchenko wrote \"Little Russia\" or \"Little Russian\" twenty one times, and \"Ukraine\" 3 times (\"Ukrainian\" – never) and (\"Kozak\" – 74). At the same time in his poetry he used only \"Ukraine\" (and \"Ukrainian\" – never). Roman Khrapachevsky, [http://ua.mrezha.ru/rus-vs-uk.htm Rus`, Little Russia and Ukraine] {{webarchive
column5: date=July 2016}} In his prominent work ''Two Russian nationalities,'' Kostomarov uses ''Southern Russia'' and ''Little Russia'' interchangeably.<ref name=Kostdve>Костомаров М. Две русские народности // Основа. – СПб., 1861. – Март.</ref> [[Mykhailo Drahomanov]] titled his first fundamental historic work ''Little Russia in its literature'' (1867–1870).<ref name=DrahoMalorossiya>Михаил Драгоманов, [http://izbornyk.org.ua/drag/drag01.htm Малороссия в ее словесности], Вестник Европы. – 1870. – Июнь</ref> Different prominent artists (e.g., [[Mykola Pymonenko]], [[Kostyantyn Trutovsky]], Nikolay Aleksandrovich Sergeyev, photographer [[Sergey Prokudin-Gorsky]], etc.), many of whom were native to the territory of modern-day Ukraine, used ''Little Russia'' in the titles of their paintings of Ukrainian landscapes.

column1: The term ''Little Russian language'' was used by the state authorities in the first [[Russian Empire Census]], conducted in 1897.
The term ''Little Russia,'' which traces its origin to medieval times, was once widely used as the name for the geographic territory.{{citation needed
column2: date=July 2012}} The first appearance of the name ''Ukraine'' (''Ukrayina'') was in 12th-century chronicles;{{citation needed
column3: date=December 2018}} it was used sporadically from the mid-17th century until it was reintroduced in the 19th century by several writers making a conscious effort to awaken Ukrainian national awareness.<ref name=UkrainiansEnc>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/U/K/Ukrainians.htm Ukrainians] in the [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ Encyclopedia of Ukraine]</ref> But it was not until the 20th century when the modern term ''Ukraine'' started to prevail, while ''Little Russia'' gradually fell out of use.

column1: The term ''Little Russia'' (Rus' Minor) is now anachronistic when used to refer to the country Ukraine and the modern Ukrainian nation, its language, culture, etc. Such usage is typically perceived as conveying an imperialist view that the Ukrainian territory and people (\"Little Russians\") belong to \"one, indivisible Russia.\"<ref>Analysis of the events of the Orange Revolution in Ukraine by Prof. Y. Petrovsky-Shtern [http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20051/22 Retrieved] May 23, 2007</ref> Today, many Ukrainians consider the term disparaging, indicative of an \"older brother\" attitude,{{Citation needed
column2: date=May 2007}} and of imperial Russian (and [[Soviet Empire
column3: Soviet]]) suppression of Ukrainian nationalism. It has continued to be used in Russian nationalist discourse, in which modern Ukrainians are presented as a single people in a united [[Russian Empire
column5: ru}} Mikhail Smolin, \"[http://rusidea.org/?a=37004 Преодоление «украинства» и общерусское единство](Overcoming the \"Ukrainianness\" and the all-Russian unity), «Вестник Юго-Западной Руси», №1, 2006 г.</ref> This has provoked new hostility toward and disapproval of the term by some Ukrainians.<ref name=UkrainiansEnc/>

column3: translit=malorosiystvo}}) is defined by some Ukrainian authors as a provincial complex they see in parts of the Ukrainian community due to its lengthy existence within the Russian Empire. They describe it as an \"indifferent, and sometimes a negative stance towards Ukrainian national-statehood traditions and aspirations, and often as active support of Russian culture and of Russian imperial policies.\"<ref name=Dovidn>Ihor Pidkova (editor), Roman Shust (editor), \"[http://history.franko.lviv.ua/dovidnyk.htm Dovidnyk z istorii Ukrainy]\", 3-Volumes, \"[http://history.franko.lviv.ua/IIm.htm Малоросійство]\" (t. 2), Kiev, 1993–1999, {{ISBN
column6: 966-504-237-8}} (t. 3).</ref> [[Mykhailo Drahomanov]], who used the terms ''Little Russia'' and ''Little Russian'' in his historical works,<ref name=DrahoMalorossiya/> applied the term ''Little Russianness'' to Russified Ukrainians, whose national character was formed under \"alien pressure and influence\" and who consequently adopted the \"worse qualities of other nationalities and lost the better ones of their own.\"<ref name=Dovidn/> Ukrainian conservative ideologue and politician [[Vyacheslav Lypynsky]] defined the term as \"the malaise of statelessness.\"<ref>Ihor Hyrych. \"Den\". Lypynsky on the imperative of political independence [http://www.day.kiev.ua/261013/ Retrieved] May 23, 2007</ref> The same inferiority complex has been said to apply to the Ukrainians of [[Galicia (Central Europe)
column7: Galicia]] with respect to [[Poland]] (''gente ruthenus, natione polonus''). The related term ''Magyarony'' has been used to describe [[Magyarization
column8: Magyarized]] Rusyns in [[Carpathian Ruthenia]] who advocated for the union of that region with [[Hungary]].<ref name=Dovidn/>

column1: The term \"Little Russians\" has also been used to denote stereotypically uneducated, rustic Ukrainians exhibiting little or no self-esteem. The uncouth stage persona of popular Ukrainian singer and performer [[Verka Serduchka
column2: Andriy Mykhailovych Danylko]] is an embodiment of this stereotype; his [[Surzhyk]]-speaking [[Drag_queen
column3: drag]] persona [[Verka Serduchka]] has also been seen as perpetuating this demeaning image.<ref>{{in lang
column4: uk}} Serhiy Hrabovsky. \"Telekritika\".  [http://telekritika.kiev.ua/articles/176/0/9180/hrabovsky_verka/ \"Sour Milk of Andriy Danylko\"] Retrieved on May 23, 2007</ref><ref>{{in lang
column5: ru}} [http://www.korrespondent.net/main/191290/ НРУ: Верка Сердючка – позор Полтавы], ''[[Korrespondent.net]]'', 22 May 2007</ref> Danylko himself usually laughs off such criticism of his work, and many art critics argue that his success with the Ukrainian public is rooted in the unquestionable authenticity of his presentation.<ref>{{in lang
column6: ru}} Алексей Радинский, [http://www.korrespondent.net/main/182804 Полюбить Сердючку], ''[[Korrespondent]]'', 17 March 2007</ref>

column1: On 18 July 2017, the head of the self-proclaimed state [[Donetsk People's Republic]], [[Alexander Zakharchenko]], announced its intention to form a federation with the [[Luhansk People's Republic]] (LPR) called ''Little Russia'' (''Malorossiya''). Its goal was to absorb the \"former Ukraine,\" which he declared a \"[[failed state]].\"<ref name=\"telegraphjul17\">{{cite web
column3: title=Separatists in Ukraine declare creation of new 'state' Malorossiya
column9: author=Litvinova, Daria}}</ref><ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-separatists-malorussia-criticism-zakharchenko-plotnitsky-poroshenko/28623190.html Ukraine Separatists Criticized Over Call For Creation Of 'Little Russia'], [[Radio Free Europe]] (18 July 2017)</ref> A constitution was published and a flag designed for the new state.<ref>[https://medium.com/dfrlab/from-malorossiya-with-love-8765ed30242d From “Malorossiya” With Love?], [[Atlantic Council]]'s Digital Forensic Research Lab (18 July 2017)</ref> The same day, the press service of the LPR released a statement from LPR leader [[Igor Plotnitsky]], stating that the LPR was \"not taking part in the project.\"<ref>[http://tass.com/politics/956825 Malorossiya project is personal initiative of self-proclaimed republic's leader — Kremlin], [[TASS news agency]] (18 July 2017)</ref> Russian authorities publicly rejected the proposal.<ref>{{Cite news

column1: On 22 July, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' claimed that the idea behind the 18 July announcement had actually came from circles close to the [[Moscow_Kremlin
column2: Kremlin]] via the Russian nationalist [[Zakhar Prilepin]]. Prilepin said in an interview that the rationale behind the proposed state was that the separatists no longer could be called such because they were now supporting a unified state.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/8443f586-6de7-11e7-bfeb-33fe0c5b7eaa? Call for new Ukraine state serves Moscow’s goals], [[Financial Times]] (22 July 2017)</ref>

column1:
On 9 August, Zakharchenko stated that the proposed state would not be named \"Malorossiya\" (\"Little Russia\") because \"many feel repulsed by\" the name.[https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/separatists-leader-zakharchenko-rules-malorossiya-name.html Separatists leader Zakharchenko rules out Malorossiya as name], [[Kyiv Post]] (10 August 2017)
[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-russia-donetsk-zakharchenko-dumps-malorossia/28669230.html Russia-Backed Separatist Leader Says 'Little Russia' A Bust],

column2: ru}} Rigelman Alexander. (1847) [http://new.runivers.ru/lib/book4494/53816/ Chronicles the story of Little Russia and its people, and a Cossack general] (Из истории московско-крымских отношений в первой половине XVII века) at [[Runivers.ru]] in [[DjVu]] and [[PDF]] formats
ru}} Bantysh-Kamensky Dmitry. (1830) [http://new.runivers.ru/lib/book4342/ History of Little Russia] (История Малой России) at [[Runivers.ru]] in [[DjVu]] and [[PDF]] formats
For the area of London, see [[Little Russia, London]]}}

column1: [[File:Little Great and white Russias 1747 Bowen map.jpg
column4: A fragment of the “new and accurate map of Europe collected from the best authorities...” by [[Emanuel Bowen]] published in 1747 in his ''A complete system of geography''. [[Left-bank Ukraine]] is shown as “Little Russia”. [[Great Russia
column7: Red Russia]]s are also seen, and the legend “Ukrain” straddles the [[Dnieper]] river near [[Poltava]].]]

column1: '''Little Russia''', sometimes '''Little [[Etymology of Rus and derivatives
column19: Mikrá Rosía}}), is a geographical and historical term used to describe the modern-day territories of Belarus and Ukraine, first used by [[Galicia (Central Europe)
column21: Bolesław-Jerzy II]], who in 1335 signed his decrees as ''Dux totius Russiæ minoris.''<ref>[[:ru:Ефименко, Александра Яковлевна
column22: Ефименко, А.Я]]. История украинского народа. К., \"Лыбедь\", 1990, стр. 87. </ref>

column1: With time, \"Little Russia\" developed into a political and geographical concept in Russia, referring to most of the territory of modern-day [[Ukraine]] before the 20th century. Accordingly, derivatives such as \"Little Russian\" ({{lang-ru
column4: Malorossy}}) were commonly applied to the people, language, and culture of the area. Prior to the revolutionary events of 1917, a large part of the region's élite population adopted a [[Little Russian identity]] that competed with the local Ukrainian identity.

column1: After the collapse of the [[Russian Empire]] in 1917, and with the amalgamation of Ukrainian territories into one administrative unit (the [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]]), the term started to recede from common use. Its subsequent usage has been regarded as derogatory by Ukrainians.<ref name=\"Steele1994\">{{cite book
column5: title= Eternal Russia: Yeltsin, Gorbachev, and the Mirage of Democracy
column13: quote=Several centuries later, when Moscow became the main colonizing force, Ukrainians were given a label which they were to find insulting. [...] The Russians of Muscovy [...] were the 'Great Russians'. Ukraine was called 'Little Russia', or Malorus. Although the phrase was geographical in origin, it could not help being felt by Ukrainian nationalists as demeaning.}}</ref> The term is [[wiktionary:archaic
column14: archaic]], and Ukrainians regard its anachronistic usage as offensive.<ref>{{cite news

column3: Dialectic partition of the Russian language in 1915 (including Little Russian dialect)]]

column1: Up to the very end of the 19th century, ''Little Russia'' was the prevailing term for much of the modern territory of Ukraine controlled by the [[Russian Empire]], as well as for its people and their language. This can be seen from its usage in numerous scholarly, literary and artistic works. [[Ukrainophilia
column2: Ukrainophile]] historians [[Mykhaylo Maksymovych]], [[Nikolay Kostomarov]], Dmytro Bahaliy, and [[Volodymyr Antonovych]] acknowledged the fact that during the Russo-Polish wars, ''Ukraine'' had only a geographical meaning, referring to the borderlands of both states, but ''Little Russia'' was the [[ethnonym]] of Little (Southern) Russian people.<ref name=Khrapachevsky>In his private diary Taras Shevchenko wrote \"Little Russia\" or \"Little Russian\" twenty one times, and \"Ukraine\" 3 times (\"Ukrainian\" – never) and (\"Kozak\" – 74). At the same time in his poetry he used only \"Ukraine\" (and \"Ukrainian\" – never). Roman Khrapachevsky, [http://ua.mrezha.ru/rus-vs-uk.htm Rus`, Little Russia and Ukraine] {{webarchive
column5: date=July 2016}} In his prominent work ''Two Russian nationalities,'' Kostomarov uses ''Southern Russia'' and ''Little Russia'' interchangeably.<ref name=Kostdve>Костомаров М. Две русские народности // Основа. – СПб., 1861. – Март.</ref> [[Mykhailo Drahomanov]] titled his first fundamental historic work ''Little Russia in its literature'' (1867–1870).<ref name=DrahoMalorossiya>Михаил Драгоманов, [http://izbornyk.org.ua/drag/drag01.htm Малороссия в ее словесности], Вестник Европы. – 1870. – Июнь</ref> Different prominent artists (e.g., [[Mykola Pymonenko]], [[Kostyantyn Trutovsky]], Nikolay Aleksandrovich Sergeyev, photographer [[Sergey Prokudin-Gorsky]], etc.), many of whom were native to the territory of modern-day Ukraine, used ''Little Russia'' in the titles of their paintings of Ukrainian landscapes.

column1: The term ''Little Russian language'' was used by the state authorities in the first [[Russian Empire Census]], conducted in 1897.
The term ''Little Russia,'' which traces its origin to medieval times, was once widely used as the name for the geographic territory.{{citation needed
column2: date=July 2012}} The first appearance of the name ''Ukraine'' (''Ukrayina'') was in 12th-century chronicles;{{citation needed
column3: date=December 2018}} it was used sporadically from the mid-17th century until it was reintroduced in the 19th century by several writers making a conscious effort to awaken Ukrainian national awareness.<ref name=UkrainiansEnc>[http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/U/K/Ukrainians.htm Ukrainians] in the [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/ Encyclopedia of Ukraine]</ref> But it was not until the 20th century when the modern term ''Ukraine'' started to prevail, while ''Little Russia'' gradually fell out of use.

column1: The term ''Little Russia'' (Rus' Minor) is now anachronistic when used to refer to the country Ukraine and the modern Ukrainian nation, its language, culture, etc. Such usage is typically perceived as conveying an imperialist view that the Ukrainian territory and people (\"Little Russians\") belong to \"one, indivisible Russia.\"<ref>Analysis of the events of the Orange Revolution in Ukraine by Prof. Y. Petrovsky-Shtern [http://www.wumag.kiev.ua/index2.php?param=pgs20051/22 Retrieved] May 23, 2007</ref> Today, many Ukrainian nationalists consider the term disparaging, indicative of an \"older brother\" attitude,{{Citation needed
column2: date=May 2007}} and of imperial Russian (and [[Soviet Empire
column3: Soviet]]) suppression of Ukrainian nationalism. It has continued to be used in Russian nationalist discourse, in which modern Ukrainians are presented as a single people in a united [[Russian Empire
column5: ru}} Mikhail Smolin, \"[http://rusidea.org/?a=37004 Преодоление «украинства» и общерусское единство](Overcoming the \"Ukrainianness\" and the all-Russian unity), «Вестник Юго-Западной Руси», №1, 2006 г.</ref> This has provoked new hostility toward and disapproval of the term by some Ukrainians.<ref name=UkrainiansEnc/>

column3: translit=malorosiystvo}}) is defined by some Ukrainian authors as a provincial complex they see in parts of the Ukrainian community due to its lengthy existence within the Russian Empire. They describe it as an \"indifferent, and sometimes a negative stance towards Ukrainian national-statehood traditions and aspirations, and often as active support of Russian culture and of Russian imperial policies.\"<ref name=Dovidn>Ihor Pidkova (editor), Roman Shust (editor), \"[http://history.franko.lviv.ua/dovidnyk.htm Dovidnyk z istorii Ukrainy]\", 3-Volumes, \"[http://history.franko.lviv.ua/IIm.htm Малоросійство]\" (t. 2), Kiev, 1993–1999, {{ISBN
column6: 966-504-237-8}} (t. 3).</ref> [[Mykhailo Drahomanov]], who used the terms ''Little Russia'' and ''Little Russian'' in his historical works,<ref name=DrahoMalorossiya/> applied the term ''Little Russianness'' to Russified Ukrainians, whose national character was formed under \"alien pressure and influence\" and who consequently adopted the \"worse qualities of other nationalities and lost the better ones of their own.\"<ref name=Dovidn/> Ukrainian conservative ideologue and politician [[Vyacheslav Lypynsky]] defined the term as \"the malaise of statelessness.\"<ref>Ihor Hyrych. \"Den\". Lypynsky on the imperative of political independence [http://www.day.kiev.ua/261013/ Retrieved] May 23, 2007</ref> The same inferiority complex has been said to apply to the Ukrainians of [[Galicia (Central Europe)
column7: Galicia]] with respect to [[Poland]] (''gente ruthenus, natione polonus''). The related term ''Magyarony'' has been used to describe [[Magyarization
column8: Magyarized]] Rusyns in [[Carpathian Ruthenia]] who advocated for the union of that region with [[Hungary]].<ref name=Dovidn/>

column1: The term \"Little Russians\" has also been used to denote stereotypically uneducated, rustic Ukrainians exhibiting little or no self-esteem. The uncouth stage persona of popular Ukrainian singer and performer [[Verka Serduchka
column2: Andriy Mykhailovych Danylko]] is an embodiment of this stereotype; his [[Surzhyk]]-speaking [[Drag_queen
column3: drag]] persona [[Verka Serduchka]] has also been seen as perpetuating this demeaning image.<ref>{{in lang
column4: uk}} Serhiy Hrabovsky. \"Telekritika\".  [http://telekritika.kiev.ua/articles/176/0/9180/hrabovsky_verka/ \"Sour Milk of Andriy Danylko\"] Retrieved on May 23, 2007</ref><ref>{{in lang
column5: ru}} [http://www.korrespondent.net/main/191290/ НРУ: Верка Сердючка – позор Полтавы], ''[[Korrespondent.net]]'', 22 May 2007</ref> Danylko himself usually laughs off such criticism of his work, and many art critics argue that his success with the Ukrainian public is rooted in the unquestionable authenticity of his presentation.<ref>{{in lang
column6: ru}} Алексей Радинский, [http://www.korrespondent.net/main/182804 Полюбить Сердючку], ''[[Korrespondent]]'', 17 March 2007</ref>

column1: On 18 July 2017, the head of the self-proclaimed state [[Donetsk People's Republic]], [[Alexander Zakharchenko]], announced its intention to form a federation with the [[Luhansk People's Republic]] (LPR) called ''Little Russia'' (''Malorossiya''). Its goal was to absorb the \"former Ukraine,\" which he declared a \"[[failed state]].\"<ref name=\"telegraphjul17\">{{cite web
column3: title=Separatists in Ukraine declare creation of new 'state' Malorossiya
column9: author=Litvinova, Daria}}</ref><ref>[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-separatists-malorussia-criticism-zakharchenko-plotnitsky-poroshenko/28623190.html Ukraine Separatists Criticized Over Call For Creation Of 'Little Russia'], [[Radio Free Europe]] (18 July 2017)</ref> A constitution was published and a flag designed for the new state.<ref>[https://medium.com/dfrlab/from-malorossiya-with-love-8765ed30242d From “Malorossiya” With Love?], [[Atlantic Council]]'s Digital Forensic Research Lab (18 July 2017)</ref> The same day, the press service of the LPR released a statement from LPR leader [[Igor Plotnitsky]], stating that the LPR was \"not taking part in the project.\"<ref>[http://tass.com/politics/956825 Malorossiya project is personal initiative of self-proclaimed republic's leader — Kremlin], [[TASS news agency]] (18 July 2017)</ref> Russian authorities publicly rejected the proposal.<ref>{{Cite news

column1: On 22 July, the ''[[Financial Times]]'' claimed that the idea behind the 18 July announcement had actually came from circles close to the [[Moscow_Kremlin
column2: Kremlin]] via the Russian nationalist [[Zakhar Prilepin]]. Prilepin said in an interview that the rationale behind the proposed state was that the separatists no longer could be called such because they were now supporting a unified state.<ref>[https://www.ft.com/content/8443f586-6de7-11e7-bfeb-33fe0c5b7eaa? Call for new Ukraine state serves Moscow’s goals], [[Financial Times]] (22 July 2017)</ref>

column1:
On 9 August, Zakharchenko stated that the proposed state would not be named \"Malorossiya\" (\"Little Russia\") because \"many feel repulsed by\" the name.[https://www.kyivpost.com/ukraine-politics/separatists-leader-zakharchenko-rules-malorossiya-name.html Separatists leader Zakharchenko rules out Malorossiya as name], [[Kyiv Post]] (10 August 2017)
[https://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-russia-donetsk-zakharchenko-dumps-malorossia/28669230.html Russia-Backed Separatist Leader Says 'Little Russia' A Bust],

column2: ru}} Rigelman Alexander. (1847) [http://new.runivers.ru/lib/book4494/53816/ Chronicles the story of Little Russia and its people, and a Cossack general] (Из истории московско-крымских отношений в первой половине XVII века) at [[Runivers.ru]] in [[DjVu]] and [[PDF]] formats
ru}} Bantysh-Kamensky Dmitry. (1830) [http://new.runivers.ru/lib/book4342/ History of Little Russia] (История Малой России) at [[Runivers.ru]] in [[DjVu]] and [[PDF]] formats

column1: '''Yang Joon-il''' (born 19 August 1969), also known as '''Joon-il Yang''', '''JIY''' and '''V2''', is a Korean-American singer-songwriter. Nicknamed the \"G-Dragon of the 1990s\", Yang made his debut in 1991 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". He was active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993 before he was banned to perform on TV. He fled back to America disappearing away from the public scene. He recently gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=50歲韓歌手撞樣 封「90年代GD」引關注
column8: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column22: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene
column26: date=31 December 2019 }}</ref> As of 2020, he is active in various fields such as fan meeting, book writing, public appearances, lectures, commercials, beauty and fashion related activities.

column1: Yang was born in [[Vietnam]] during the [[Vietnam War
column2: war]] in 1969 and spent his childhood in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref> Yang emigrated to the [[United States]] with his family at age nine and grew up in [[Los Angeles]]. After one year of dating Yang married a woman who fell in love at first sight in 2006 and the first son was born in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=양준일…아내와 인연, 결혼 이유 첫 고백 “한눈에 반했다”

column1: When he was in [[Glendale High School (Glendale, California)
column2: Glendale High School]] in LA, he was persuaded to make a debut as an entertainer by the late Hollywood actor [[Soon-Tek Oh
column3: Soon-tek Oh]], who was a member to the same church.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=故 오순택 누구?...양준일과 미국서 깊은 인연 {{!}} 텐아시아
column11: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang was a soloist in his high school choir. He took classes at [https://www.jrpowersphilly.com/ John Robert Powers Modeling, Acting Agency & Finishing School] in [[Philadelphia]] to prepare for his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=‘배철수 잼’ 양준일, 발라드 가수 데뷔 비하인드...‘리베카’ 어쿠스틱 버전 공개[종합]

column1: He entered [[University of Southern California]] [[USC Marshall School of Business
column4: title=[코리아타임스 뉴스] 시간여행자 양준일, 30년이 지나서야 인정받다
column8: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> During his studies, he was selected by Lee Beom-hee, who was the famous composer of the day.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=양준일 리베카 신드롬 열풍 “역주행 아이콘 양준일 누구?”
column14: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang dropped out to debut as a singer in Korea in 1990.

column1: Yang debuted in 1991 at the age of 22 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". \"Rebecca\" and \"Help me Cupid!\" were performed on the air, but not a big hit. His 2nd full length album was released in 1992. He released other hit songs like \"Dance with Me Miss\" (1992) and \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\" (1992).<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /><ref name=\"koreajoongangdaily\" /><ref name=\"yonhap\" />
He was credited as the first pop musician to introduce Korean audiences to the [[new jack swing]] genre, which was popular in the mid-1980s and early 1990s in the U.S.

Active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993, he suddenly disappeared from the public scene and returned to the U.S. In a 2019 interview with the [[The Korea Times]], he revealed that \"he was hated by many for his unusual looks and songs.\" Some also threw rocks during his performance at an open-air stage. While a 10-year visa he held in Korea as a U.S. national had to be recertified every six months, he was denied an extension to his visa for no reason by an official at the Immigration Office. His nationality as an American also made it hard for him to gain acceptance in South Korea.

In 2001, he made another debut as JIY, a member of a music band V2, with a third album \"Fantasy\". V2 meant his \"Version 2\". He was in active under the name of JIY instead of his real name, Yang Joon-il. He lied about his age and made a big change in his look.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='배철수 잼' 양준일, 험난했던 인생사→신드롬에 대한 솔직 고백까지(종합)
column7: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> He hid his true identity as music producers told him he would not make it again due to his previous controversial image in Korea. His new song \"Fantasy\", composed by Valery Gaina of [[Cruise (band)
column8: Cruise]], enjoyed a brief popularity before he finally put an end to his music career. Due to the agency's circumstances, it became impossible to work as a musician and after that he worked as an English teacher for 14 years.  In 2015, he returned to the United States. Because of his age, he had a hard time finding work. He worked as a warehouse worker, office cleaner, and restaurant server.

column1: In 2019, he gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past. He sang \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGIndlf_xU4&t=64s Rebecca]\", [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QU462sGMclc \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\", \"Dance With Me Miss\"], and \"Fantasy\". Still slim in figure and soulful in his performance, he dazzled the audience and show hosts.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column7: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> When asked his next plans amid this viral syndrome, he simply said: \"I don't make any plans; I just focus on fully living every moment. If there's any plans, I hope to live as a humble husband and dad.\" When the show hosts asked him to give a message to 20-year-old himself living 30 years ago, Yang said: \"I know nothing will happen how you want. But don't worry, everything will come out perfectly in the end.\"<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /> After his fame skyrocketed again after his appearance on the show, he quit his job at the restaurant to focus on his entertainment career.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title='G-Dragon of the 90s' Yang Joon Il visits JTBC's 'News Room' after his surging popularity, says he was working at a restaurant in Florida

column1: On December 25, Christmas Day, he appeared on [[JTBC Newsroom]]. He said \"It's like a dream every day\", \"I've been trying to get rid of my prejudice against myself, which is full of my mind as if I had to abandon my unhappiness before I was happy.\"  \"There are no more tears\" Yang said, adding that his powerful fandom, which claims to be a support group, is also a big boost to Yang.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Celebrity of celebrity, Yang Joon-il Syndrome in Korea {{!}} HaB Korea.net

column1: On December 31, Yang met with fans through two official fan meeting events. \"Are you really here to see me?\"he said, tearing up with joy. \"This is my first time. I didn't imagine any of this. I'm so grateful.\"<ref name=\":1\" />  In a press conference at a fan meeting, he revealed that his sole dream of becoming a K-pop star in his 20s was finally accomplished now, at age 50.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene

The title of the program is meant to commemorate his debut year, 1991 and 2019 when he was recovered.<ref>{{Cite web

A series of the interviews with the behind-the-scenes of photo shooting for his book was released also.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3qzBsWHvic interview-Question From Yang Joon Il] On the 9th, Yang opened his official YouTube channel, [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWagJUPy0iR5Cf8hafiYM-w Official Yang Joon Il]. The number of subscribers has spiked up to over 15K in a single day.<ref>{{Cite web

column5: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> On Valentine's day, on Febraury 14, [Yang Joon Il Maybe] was officially released.

Two of them went on satage with his song \"Dance with Me\" released in 1992.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=degunNXQVtA practice video version] On the 16th, Yang was shown as a lecturer on \"Sebasi Talk\". The title of the lecture was <Message to unhappy people in competition>. It hit 1 million view mark in 2 days.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: '''Yang Joon-il''' (born 19 August 1969), also known as '''Joon-il Yang''', '''JIY''' and '''V2''', is a Korean-American singer-songwriter. Nicknamed the \"G-Dragon of the 1990s\", Yang made his debut in 1991 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". He was active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993 before he was banned to perform on TV. He fled back to America disappearing away from the public scene. He recently gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=50歲韓歌手撞樣 封「90年代GD」引關注
column8: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column22: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene
column26: date=31 December 2019 }}</ref> As of 2020, he is active in various fields such as fan meeting, book writing, public appearances, lectures, commercials, beauty and fashion related activities.

column1: Yang was born in [[Vietnam]] during the [[Vietnam War
column2: war]] in 1969 and spent his childhood in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref> Yang emigrated to the [[United States]] with his family at age nine and grew up in [[Los Angeles]]. After one year of dating Yang married a woman who fell in love at first sight in 2006 and the first son was born in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=양준일…아내와 인연, 결혼 이유 첫 고백 “한눈에 반했다”

column1: When he was in [[Glendale High School (Glendale, California)
column2: Glendale High School]] in LA, he was persuaded to make a debut as an entertainer by the late Hollywood actor [[Soon-Tek Oh
column3: Soon-tek Oh]], who was a member to the same church.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=故 오순택 누구?...양준일과 미국서 깊은 인연 {{!}} 텐아시아
column11: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang was a soloist in his high school choir. He took classes at [https://www.jrpowersphilly.com/ John Robert Powers Modeling, Acting Agency & Finishing School] in [[Philadelphia]] to prepare for his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=‘배철수 잼’ 양준일, 발라드 가수 데뷔 비하인드...‘리베카’ 어쿠스틱 버전 공개[종합]

column1: He entered [[University of Southern California]] [[USC Marshall School of Business
column4: title=[코리아타임스 뉴스] 시간여행자 양준일, 30년이 지나서야 인정받다
column8: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> During his studies, he was selected by Lee Beom-hee, who was the famous composer of the day.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=양준일 리베카 신드롬 열풍 “역주행 아이콘 양준일 누구?”
column14: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang dropped out to debut as a singer in Korea in 1990.

column1: Yang debuted in 1991 at the age of 22 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". \"Rebecca\" and \"Help me Cupid!\" were performed on the air, but not a big hit. His 2nd full length album was released in 1992. He released other hit songs like \"Dance with Me Miss\" (1992) and \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\" (1992).<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /><ref name=\"koreajoongangdaily\" /><ref name=\"yonhap\" />
He was credited as the first pop musician to introduce Korean audiences to the [[new jack swing]] genre, which was popular in the mid-1980s and early 1990s in the U.S.

Active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993, he suddenly disappeared from the public scene and returned to the U.S. In a 2019 interview with the [[The Korea Times]], he revealed that \"he was hated by many for his unusual looks and songs.\" Some also threw rocks during his performance at an open-air stage. While a 10-year visa he held in Korea as a U.S. national had to be recertified every six months, he was denied an extension to his visa for no reason by an official at the Immigration Office. His nationality as an American also made it hard for him to gain acceptance in South Korea.

In 2001, he made another debut as JIY, a member of a music band V2, with a third album \"Fantasy\". V2 meant his \"Version 2\". He was in active under the name of JIY instead of his real name, Yang Joon-il. He lied about his age and made a big change in his look.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='배철수 잼' 양준일, 험난했던 인생사→신드롬에 대한 솔직 고백까지(종합)
column7: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> He hid his true identity as music producers told him he would not make it again due to his previous controversial image in Korea. His new song \"Fantasy\", composed by Valery Gaina of [[Cruise (band)
column8: Cruise]], enjoyed a brief popularity before he finally put an end to his music career. Due to the agency's circumstances, it became impossible to work as a musician and after that he worked as an English teacher for 14 years.  In 2015, he returned to the United States. Because of his age, he had a hard time finding work. He worked as a warehouse worker, office cleaner, and restaurant server.

column1: In 2019, he gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past. He sang \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGIndlf_xU4&t=64s Rebecca]\", [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QU462sGMclc \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\", \"Dance With Me Miss\"], and \"Fantasy\". Still slim in figure and soulful in his performance, he dazzled the audience and show hosts.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column7: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> When asked his next plans amid this viral syndrome, he simply said: \"I don't make any plans; I just focus on fully living every moment. If there's any plans, I hope to live as a humble husband and dad.\" When the show hosts asked him to give a message to 20-year-old himself living 30 years ago, Yang said: \"I know nothing will happen how you want. But don't worry, everything will come out perfectly in the end.\"<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /> After his fame skyrocketed again after his appearance on the show, he quit his job at the restaurant to focus on his entertainment career.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title='G-Dragon of the 90s' Yang Joon Il visits JTBC's 'News Room' after his surging popularity, says he was working at a restaurant in Florida

column1: On December 25, Christmas Day, he appeared on [[JTBC Newsroom]]. He said \"It's like a dream every day\", \"I've been trying to get rid of my prejudice against myself, which is full of my mind as if I had to abandon my unhappiness before I was happy.\"  \"There are no more tears\" Yang said, adding that his powerful fandom, which claims to be a support group, is also a big boost to Yang.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Celebrity of celebrity, Yang Joon-il Syndrome in Korea {{!}} HaB Korea.net

column1: On December 31, Yang met with fans through two official fan meeting events. \"Are you really here to see me?\"he said, tearing up with joy. \"This is my first time. I didn't imagine any of this. I'm so grateful.\"<ref name=\":1\" />  In a press conference at a fan meeting, he revealed that his sole dream of becoming a K-pop star in his 20s was finally accomplished now, at age 50.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene

column1: Just a few days before the fan meeting he shot a commercial with Lotte Home Shopping<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='GD of the 90's Yang Joon Il lands a Lotte Home Shopping CF
column5: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> for the first time in his life. He spent that money to rent an apartment in Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=‘해투4’ 양준일 “생애 첫 광고모델료 받아 韓아파트 보증금 마련”

column1: On January 3 in 2020, Yang created his account on [[Instagram]].[https://www.instagram.com/jiytime/?hl=ko jiytime] On the 4th, he performed his debut song \"Rebecca\" on [[MBC TV
column2: MBC]]'s \"[[Show! Music Core]]\" after 28 years after his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=At 50, forgotten Korean-American singer compares to G-Dragon
column8: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> Yang appeared himself a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buy_iFyS8Hg fan video], a parody of his own 90's fashion style.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inogwFkBgY4 interview] JTBC's special feature <Sugar Man, Yang Joon-il, 91.19> aired on the 16th and 23rd. The title of the program is meant to commemorate his debut year, 1991 and 2019 when he was recovered.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=JTBC set to air a variety special focused on Yang Joon Il

column1: On Febraury 3, his photo essay [Yang Joon Il Maybe] started a pre-sale. On the first day, over 15,000 copies were pre-sold and it became bestseller. A series of the interviews with the behind-the-scenes of photo shooting for his book was released also.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3qzBsWHvic interview-Question From Yang Joon Il] On the 9th, Yang opened his official YouTube channel, [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWagJUPy0iR5Cf8hafiYM-w Official Yang Joon Il]. The number of subscribers has spiked up to over 15K in a single day.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon Il opens up his official YouTube channel!
column5: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> On Valentine's day, on Febraury 14, [Yang Joon Il Maybe] was officially released.

publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]}}</ref>  Whitley County is the 49th largest county in Indiana. The [[county seat]] is [[Columbia City, Indiana

column1: It is part of the [[Fort Wayne Metropolitan Statistical Area]] and the [[Fort Wayne, Indiana
According to the 2010 census, the county has a total area of {{convert

The first non-Native American settlers arrived in what is now Whitley County in 1835.  They arrived as a result of the end of the [[Black Hawk War]] as well as the completion of the [[Erie Canal]].  They consisted entirely of settlers from [[New England]]. These were \"[[Yankee]]\" settlers, that is to say they were descended from the [[English people
column2: English]] [[Puritans]] who settled [[New England]] in the colonial era.  They were primarily members of the [[Congregational church
column3: Congregational Church]] though due to the [[Second Great Awakening]] many of them had converted to [[Methodism]] and some had become [[Baptists]] before coming to what is now Whitley County.  When the [[New England]] settlers arrived in what is now Whitley County there was nothing but a dense virgin forest and wild prairie. Whitley County was formed in 1838. It was named for Col. [[William Whitley]], who was killed in the [[Battle of the Thames]] in the [[War of 1812]].  In the late 1870s immigrants began arriving from [[Germany]] and [[Ireland]].<ref>{{cite book
column4: author=De Witt Clinton Goodrich & Charles Richard Tuttle
column8: title=An Illustrated History of the State of Indiana

column1: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana bar. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[Recorder of deeds
column3: surveyor]], and circuit [[court clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column4: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

column3: PD/sqmi}}. There were 14,281 housing units at an average density of {{convert

column2: title=Population, Housing Units, Area, and Density: 2010 - County

column1: }}</ref> The racial makeup of the county was 97.6% white, 0.3% Asian, 0.3% American Indian, 0.3% black or African American, 0.4% from other races, and 1.1% from two or more races. Those of Hispanic or Latino origin made up 1.5% of the population.<ref name=\"census-dp1\"/> In terms of ancestry, 38.2% were [[Germans

column2: title=DP02 SELECTED SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS IN THE UNITED STATES – 2006-2010 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates

column1: Of the 13,001 households, 32.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.4% were married couples living together, 9.2% had a female householder with no husband present, 29.0% were non-families, and 24.1% of all households were made up of individuals. The average household size was 2.53 and the average family size was 2.99. The median age was 40.1 years.<ref name=\"census-dp1\"/>

The median income for a household in the county was $47,697 and the median income for a family was $63,487. Males had a median income of $44,883 versus $30,724 for females. The per capita income for the county was $24,644. About 5.1% of families and 6.8% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 7.2% of those under age 18 and 7.6% of those age 65 or over.<ref name=\"census-dp3\">{{cite web

The median income for a household in the county was $47,697 and the median income for a family was $63,487. Males had a median income of $44,883 versus $30,724 for females. The per capita income for the county was $24,644. About 5.1% of families and 6.8% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 7.2% of those under age 18 and 7.6% of those age 65 or over.<ref name=\"census-dp3\">{{cite web

column1: Shelby County was organized in 1821. It was named for Gen. [[Isaac Shelby]], who defeated the British at the [[Battle of Kings Mountain]] in the [[American Revolutionary War
column2: Revolutionary War]]. Shelby then became the first [[Governor of Kentucky]]. During the [[War of 1812]], he led the army of Kentucky into [[Canada]], and defeated the British at the decisive [[Battle of the Thames]] in 1813.

column1: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[Recorder of deeds
column3: surveyor]], and circuit [[court clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversee different parts of the county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column4: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

column2: era=5th century BC to 2nd century AD; continued as a [[literary language]] until the 20th century

Some sources distinguish between Classical Chinese as strictly the language of the ancient classics and Literary Chinese as the classical style of writing used throughout Chinese history prior to the [[May Fourth Movement]] (see \"[[Classical Chinese#Definitions
column3: Definitions]]\")}} is the language of the classic literature from the end of the [[Spring and Autumn period]] through to the end of the [[Han dynasty]], a written form of [[Old Chinese]]. Classical Chinese is a traditional style of [[written Chinese]] that evolved from the classical language, making it different from any modern [[Chinese spoken language
column4: spoken form of Chinese]]. Literary Chinese was used for almost all formal writing in [[China]] until the early 20th century, and also, during various periods, in [[Japan]], [[Korea]] and [[Vietnam]]. Among Chinese speakers, Literary Chinese has been largely replaced by [[written vernacular Chinese]], a style of writing that is similar to modern spoken [[Mandarin Chinese]], while speakers of non-Chinese languages have largely abandoned Literary Chinese in favor of local vernaculars.

column13: 古文}})<ref name=\"Nguyễn Tri Tài 2002 p5\">{{cite book
column17: title=Giáo trình tiếng Hán. Tập I: Cơ sở
column18: publisher=Nhà xuất bản Đại học Quốc gia Thành phố Hồ Chí Minh
column23: 文言}})<ref name=\"Nguyễn Tri Tài 2002 p5\"/> in Vietnamese.

column1: Strictly speaking, Classical Chinese refers to the written language of the classical period of Chinese literature, from the end of the [[Spring and Autumn period]] (early 5th century BC) to the end of the [[Han dynasty]] (AD 220),<ref>{{cite book
column8: isbn = 0-521-29653-6}}</ref> while Literary Chinese is the form of written Chinese used from the end of the [[Han Dynasty]] to the early 20th century, when it was replaced by vernacular written Chinese. It is often also referred to as \"Classical Chinese\", but [[Sinology
column9: sinologists]] generally distinguish it from the language of the early period. During this period the dialects of China became more and more disparate and thus the Classical written language became less and less representative of the [[varieties of Chinese]] (cf. [[Classical Latin]], which was contemporary to the Han Dynasty, and the [[Romance languages]] of Europe). Although authors sought to write in the style of the Classics, the similarity decreased over the centuries due to their imperfect understanding of the older language, the influence of their own speech, and the addition of new words.<ref>Norman (1988), pp. 83–84, 108–109.</ref>

column1: This situation, the [[adoption of Chinese literary culture
column2: use of Literary Chinese throughout the Chinese cultural sphere]] despite the existence of disparate regional vernaculars, is called [[diglossia]].  It can be compared to the position of [[Classical Arabic]] relative to the various [[Varieties of Arabic
column3: regional vernaculars]] in Arab lands, or of [[Latin]] in medieval Europe. The Romance languages continued to evolve, influencing Latin texts of the same period, so that by the [[Middle Ages]], [[Medieval Latin]] included many usages that would have baffled the [[Ancient Rome
column4: Romans]]. The coexistence of Classical Chinese and the native languages of Japan, Korea and Vietnam can be compared to the use of Latin in nations that natively speak non-Latin-derived [[Germanic languages]] or [[Slavic languages]], to the position of Arabic in [[Persia]] or the position of the Indic language, [[Sanskrit]], in South India and Southeast Asia. However, the non-phonetic [[Chinese characters
column5: Chinese writing system]] causes a unique situation where the modern pronunciation of the classical language is far more divergent (and heterogeneous, depending on the native – not necessarily Chinese – tongue of the reader) than in analogous cases, complicating understanding and study of Classical Chinese further compared to other classical languages.

column1: Christian missionaries coined the term Wen-li ({{zh
Though composed from Chinese roots, this term was never used in that sense in Chinese,<ref>{{cite book

column2: title = Aspects of Chinese sociolinguistics: essays by Yuen Ren Chao

column1: and was rejected by non-missionary sinologues.<ref>{{cite book

column2: title=The Bible in China: the history of the Union Version or the culmination of protestant missionary Bible translation in China

quote=The term \"Wenli\" (文理) was \"an English word derived from Chinese roots but never used by the Chinese\" (Yuen 1976, 25). The original meaning is \"principles of literature (or: writing),\" but by the missionaries of the last century it was coined to stand for classical Chinese. For sinologues outside the missionary circle, the term \"wenli\" was not acceptable (\"... what the missionaries persist in calling wen li, meaning thereby the book language as opposed to the colloquial\"— Giles 1881/82, 151).

column4: The shape of the [[Oracle bone script]] character for \"person\" may have influenced that for \"harvest\" (which later came to mean \"year\").  Today, they are pronounced ''rén'' and ''nián'' in Mandarin, but their hypothesized pronunciations in [[Old Chinese]] were very similar, which may explain the resemblance.  For example, in the recent [[Reconstructions of Old Chinese#Baxter–Sagart (2014)

column2: alphabetic]] and only rarely reflect [[sound changes]].  The tentative reconstruction of [[Old Chinese]] is an endeavor only a few centuries old. As a result, Classical Chinese is not read with a reconstruction of Old Chinese pronunciation; instead, it is always read with the pronunciations of characters categorized and listed in the Phonology Dictionary (韻書; [[pinyin]]: ''yùnshū'', \"[[Rime dictionary
column3: rhyme book]]\") officially published by the Governments, originally based upon the Middle Chinese pronunciation of [[Luoyang]] in the 2nd to 4th centuries.  With the progress of time, every dynasty has updated and modified the official Phonology Dictionary.  By the time of the [[Yuan Dynasty]] and [[Ming Dynasty]], the Phonology Dictionary was based on early Mandarin.  But since the [[Imperial Examination]] required the composition of [[Shi (poetry)
column4: Shi]] genre, in non-Mandarin speaking parts of China such as [[Zhejiang]], [[Guangdong]] and [[Fujian]], pronunciation is either based on everyday speech as in [[Standard Cantonese
column5: Cantonese]]; or, in some varieties of Chinese (e.g. [[Southern Min]]), with a special set of pronunciations used for Classical Chinese or \"formal\" vocabulary and usage borrowed from Classical Chinese usage.  In practice, all varieties of Chinese combine these two extremes. Mandarin and Cantonese, for example, also have words that are pronounced one way in colloquial usage and another way when used in Classical Chinese or in specialized terms coming from Classical Chinese, though the system is not as extensive as that of Southern Min or [[Wu Chinese
column6: Wu]]. (See [[Literary and colloquial readings of Chinese characters]])

column4: Vietnamese]] readers of Classical Chinese use systems of pronunciation specific to their own languages. For example, Japanese speakers use ''On'yomi'' pronunciation when reading the [[kanji]] of words of Chinese origin such as 銀行 (ginkō) or the name for the city of Tōkyō (東京), but use ''Kun'yomi'' when the kanji represents a native word such as the reading of 行 in 行く (iku) or the reading of both characters in the name for the city of Ōsaka (大阪), and a system that aids Japanese speakers with Classical Chinese word order.

column1: Since the pronunciation of all modern varieties of Chinese is different from Old Chinese or other forms of historical Chinese (such as [[Middle Chinese]]), characters that once [[rhyme]]d in poetry may not rhyme any longer, or vice versa. Poetry and other rhyme-based writing thus becomes less coherent than the original reading must have been. However, some modern [[varieties of Chinese
column2: Chinese varieties]] have certain phonological characteristics that are closer to the older pronunciations than others, as shown by the preservation of certain rhyme structures. Some{{who
column3: date=October 2019}} believe Classical Chinese literature, especially poetry, sounds better when read in certain varieties that are believed to be closer to older pronunciations, such as Cantonese or Southern Min, because the rhyming is often lost due to sound shifts in [[Standard Chinese

column1: Another phenomenon that is common in reading Classical Chinese is [[homophone
column2: homophony]] (words that sound the same). More than 2,500 years of sound change separates Classical Chinese from any modern variety, so when reading Classical Chinese in any modern variety of Chinese (especially Mandarin) or in Japanese, Korean, or Vietnamese, many characters which originally had different pronunciations have become [[homonym]]s. There is a famous Classical Chinese poem written in the early 20th century by the linguist [[Chao Yuen Ren]] called the ''[[Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den]]'', which contains only words that are now pronounced {{IPA-cmn
column5: Mandarin]]. It was written to show how Classical Chinese has become an impractical language for speakers of modern Chinese because Classical Chinese when spoken aloud is largely incomprehensible. However the poem is perfectly comprehensible when read silently because Literary Chinese, by its very nature as a ''written'' language using a [[logographic]] writing system, can often get away with using homophones that even in spoken Old Chinese would not have been distinguishable in any way.

column1: The situation is analogous to that of some English words that are spelled differently but sound the same, such as \"meet\" and \"meat\", which were pronounced {{IPA-enm
column4: [mɛːt]}} respectively during the time of [[Chaucer]], as shown by their spelling. However, such homophones are far more common in Literary Chinese than in English. For example, the following distinct Old Chinese words are now all pronounced ''yì'' in Mandarin: ''*ŋjajs'' 議 \"discuss\", ''*ŋjət'' 仡 \"powerful\", ''*ʔjup'' 邑 \"city\", ''*ʔjək'' 億 \"100,000,000\", ''*ʔjəks'' 意 \"thought\", ''*ʔjek'' 益 \"increase\", ''*ʔjik'' 抑 \"press down\", ''*jak'' 弈 \"Chinese chess\", ''*ljit'' 逸 \"flee\", ''*ljək'' 翼 \"wing\", ''*ljek'' 易 \"change\", ''*ljeks'' 易 \"easy\" and ''*slek'' 蜴 \"lizard\".<ref>{{cite book

column2: title = A Handbook of Old Chinese Phonology

column1: Romanizations have been devised giving distinct spellings for the words of Classical Chinese, together with rules for pronunciation in various modern varieties.

The earliest was the Romanisation Interdialectique (1931–2) of French missionaries [[Henri Lamasse]], of the [[Paris Foreign Missions Society]], and Ernest Jasmin, based on [[Middle Chinese]], followed by linguist [[Wang Li (linguist)
column2: Wang Li]]'s ''wényán luómǎzì'' (1940) based on [[Old Chinese]], and Chao's [[General Chinese Romanization]] (1975).

column1: However none of these systems has seen extensive use.<ref>{{cite book
column4: contribution = Some composite phonological systems in Chinese
column8: title = The Chinese rime tables: linguistic philosophy and historical-comparative phonology
column9: series = Current Issues in Linguistic Theory
column15: title = Modern Chinese: history and sociolinguistics

column1: Classical Chinese is distinguished from written vernacular Chinese in its style, which appears extremely concise and compact to modern Chinese speakers, and to some extent in the use of different [[lexicon
column2: lexical items]] (vocabulary). An essay in Classical Chinese, for example, might use half as many [[Chinese character]]s as in vernacular Chinese to relate the same content.

column1: In terms of conciseness and compactness, Classical Chinese rarely uses words composed of two Chinese characters; nearly all words are of one [[syllable]] only. This stands directly in contrast with modern Northern Chinese varieties including Mandarin, in which two-syllable, three-syllable, and four-syllable words are extremely common, whilst although two-syllable words are also quite common within modern Southern Chinese varieties, they are still more archaic in that they use more one-syllable words than Northern Chinese varieties. This phenomenon exists, in part, because polysyllabic words evolved in Chinese to disambiguate homophones that result from sound changes. This is similar to such phenomena in English as the [[pin–pen merger
column2: ''pen–pin'' merger]] of many dialects in the American south and the [[Cot–caught merger
column3: ''caught-cot'' merger]] of most dialects of American English: because the words \"pin\" and \"pen\", as well as \"caught\" and \"cot\", sound alike in such dialects of English, a certain degree of confusion can occur unless one adds qualifiers like \"ink pen\" and \"stick pin.\" Similarly, Chinese has acquired many polysyllabic words in order to disambiguate monosyllabic words that sounded different in earlier forms of Chinese but identical in one region or another during later periods. Because Classical Chinese is based on the literary examples of ancient Chinese literature, it has almost none of the two-syllable words present in modern Chinese varieties.

column1: Classical Chinese has more [[pronoun]]s compared to the modern vernacular. In particular, whereas Mandarin has one general character to refer to the first-person pronoun (\"I\"/\"me\"), Literary Chinese has several, many of which are used as part of [[honorific]] language (see [[Chinese honorifics]]).
In [[syntax]], Classical Chinese is always ready to drop subjects and objects when a reference to them is understood ([[Pro-drop language
column2: pragmatically inferable]]). Also, words are not restrictively categorized into [[parts of speech]]: nouns are commonly used as verbs, adjectives as nouns, and so on. There is no [[copula (linguistics)
column3: copula]] in Classical Chinese, \"是\" ([[pinyin]]: ''shì'') is a copula in modern Chinese but in old Chinese it was originally a near [[demonstrative]] (\"this\"); the modern Chinese for \"this\" is \"這\" ([[pinyin]]: ''zhè'').

column1: Beyond grammar and vocabulary differences, Classical Chinese can be distinguished by literary and cultural differences: an effort to maintain [[parallelism (grammar)
column2: parallelism]] and rhythm, even in prose works, and extensive use of literary and cultural allusions, thereby also contributing to brevity.

column1: Many final particles (歇語字 ''xiēyǔzì'') and interrogative particles are found in Literary Chinese.<ref>{{cite book

column2: quote=PART III GRAMMATICAL SECTION THE FINAL PARTICLES (歇語字 hsieh1-yü3-tzu4) The Wenli-style abounds with so called final particles.
quote=PART III GRAMMATICAL SECTION THE INTERROGATIVE PARTICLES The Wen-li style particularly abounds with the interrogative particles.

column4: Classical Chinese was used in international communication between the [[Mongol Empire]] and [[Japan]]. This letter, dated 1266, was sent to [[Khubilai Khan]] from the \"King of Japan\" (日本國王)<!--The text within the image reads 日本國王, \"The King of Japan\". The Emperor of Japan was always referred to as King of Japan in Chinese texts, and prior to the Meiji Period, no Chinese dynasty ever recognised the Emperor status of the Japanese Emperor. Do not change the text within this caption.--> before the [[Mongol invasions of Japan]]; it was written in Classical Chinese. Now stored in [[Tōdai-ji]], [[Nara, Nara
column5: Nara]], [[Japan]]. There are some grammar notes on it, which were to help Japanese speakers better understand it.]]

column1: Classical Chinese was the main form used in Chinese literary works until the [[May Fourth Movement]] (1919), and was also used extensively in Japan, Korea, and Vietnam. Classical Chinese was used to write the [[Hunmin Jeongeum]] proclamation in which the modern Korean alphabet ([[hangul]]) was promulgated and the essay by [[Hu Shih]] in which he argued against using Classical Chinese and in favor of [[written vernacular Chinese]].  (The latter parallels [[De vulgari eloquentia
column2: the essay]] written by [[Dante]] in ''Latin'' in which he expounded the virtues of the vernacular ''Italian''.)  Exceptions to the use of Classical Chinese were vernacular novels such as ''[[Dream of the Red Chamber]]''.

column1: Most government documents in the [[Republic of China]] were written in Classical Chinese until reforms in the 1970s, in a reform movement spearheaded by President [[Yen Chia-kan]] to shift the written style to [[vernacular Chinese]].<ref>{{cite book
column4: chapter=The language planning situation in Taiwan
column10: title=Language planning in Nepal, Taiwan, and Sweden
column17: title=Will Taiwan break away: the rise of Taiwanese nationalism

column1: Today, pure Classical Chinese is occasionally used in formal or ceremonial occasions. The ''[[National Anthem of the Republic of China]]'' (中華民國國歌), for example, is in Classical Chinese. [[Buddhism
column2: Buddhist]] texts, or [[sutra]]s, are still preserved in Classical Chinese from the time they were composed or translated from [[Sanskrit]] sources.  In practice there is a socially accepted continuum between vernacular Chinese and Classical Chinese. For example, most official notices and formal letters are written with a number of stock Classical Chinese expressions (e.g. salutation, closing). Personal letters, on the other hand, are mostly written in vernacular, but with some Classical phrases, depending on the subject matter, the writer's level of education, etc. With the exception of professional scholars and enthusiasts, most people today cannot write in full Classical Chinese with ease.

column1: Most Chinese people with at least a middle school education are able to read basic Classical Chinese, because the ability to read (but not write) Classical Chinese is part of the Chinese [[middle school]] and [[High school (upper secondary)
column2: high school]] [[curricula]] and is part of the college entrance examination. Classical Chinese is taught primarily by presenting a classical Chinese work and including a vernacular gloss that explains the meaning of phrases. Tests on classical Chinese usually ask the student to express the meaning of a paragraph in vernacular Chinese. They often take the form of comprehension questions.

column1: The contemporary use of Classical Chinese in [[Japan]] is mainly in the field of education and the study of literature. Learning the Japanese way ([[kanbun]]) of decoding Classical Chinese is part of the [[High school (upper secondary)
column2: high school]] curriculum in Japan.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title =中学校 高等学校 学習指導要領 国語科編（試案）
column4: chapter =第七章 国語科における漢文の学習指導

column1: Classical Chinese is not a part of middle school and high school [[curricula]] in the [[Korean peninsula]] and [[Vietnam]] nowadays.{{citation needed
column2: date=January 2020}} The use of Classical Chinese in these regions is limited and is mainly in the field of [[Chinese classics

column1: In addition, many works of [[literature]] in Classical Chinese (such as [[Tang poetry]]) have been major [[cultural]] influences. However, even with knowledge of grammar and vocabulary, Classical Chinese can be difficult to understand by native speakers of modern Chinese, because of its heavy use of literary [[reference]]s and [[allusion]]s as well as its extremely abbreviated style.

column2: era=5th century BC to 2nd century AD; continued as a [[literary language]] until the 20th century

Some sources distinguish between Classical Chinese as strictly the language of the ancient classics and Literary Chinese as the classical style of writing used throughout Chinese history prior to the [[May Fourth Movement]] (see \"[[Classical Chinese#Definitions
column3: Definitions]]\")}} is the language of the classic literature from the end of the [[Spring and Autumn period]] through to the end of the [[Han dynasty]], a written form of [[Old Chinese]]. Classical Chinese is a traditional style of [[written Chinese]] that evolved from the classical language, making it different from any modern [[Chinese spoken language
column4: spoken form of Chinese]]. Literary Chinese was used for almost all formal writing in [[China]] until the early 20th century, and also, during various periods, in [[Japan]], [[Korea]] and [[Vietnam]]. Among Chinese speakers, Literary Chinese has been largely replaced by [[written vernacular Chinese]], a style of writing that is similar to modern spoken [[Mandarin Chinese]], while speakers of non-Chinese languages have largely abandoned Literary Chinese in favor of local vernaculars.
