column2: Ongoing COVID-19 viral pandemic in West Bengal, India}}
name            = 2020 COVID-19 Pandemic in West Bengal
map1            = India West Bengal COVID-19 affected districts.svg
legend1         = Districts of West Bengal, affected by COVID-19, as of 13 April 2020

arrival_date = 17 March 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days

column1: The [[2019-20 coronavirus pandemic]] was first confirmed in the Indian state of [[West Bengal]] on 17 March 2020,<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=West Bengal reports first positive case of coronavirus
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> with first positive case in [[Kolkata]]. As of 13 April 2020, the state has reported 152 COVID-19 positive cases, including  116 active cases, 7 deaths and 29 recoveries.<ref>{{Cite news
column11: title=উত্তরবঙ্গ এবং কলকাতায় আরও চার জনের মৃত্যু, প্রত্যেকেরই কোভিড-১৯ পজিটিভ

column1: {{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/India/West Bengal medical cases chart}}
Seven testing labs were authorized by ICMR:
Besides, there are 64 COVID-19 hospitals in West Bengal.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Coronavirus Lockdown: West Bengal govt asks districts to set up temporary shelters for poor, migrants

column1: *'''''4 February''''': A Kolkata Airport passenger was kept under hospital isolation. Later he was tested negative.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''17 March''''': One male, aged 18 years who had returned from the UK on 15 March, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''20 March''''': One male, aged 22 years who had returned from the UK on 13 March, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''21 March''''': One female, aged 23 years who had returned from Scotland on 19 March, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''22 March''''': One male, aged 57 years who was admitted to a private facility in North Kolkata, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web

*'''''23 March''''': First COVID-19 death was reported as the 57-year-old male patient expired at the private facility. He was a railway employee and recently came from Bilaspur. Two males (48 years and 20 years) and one female (47 years), who were in direct contacts of a positive case, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''24 March''''': One 58-year-old male, who returned from Egypt and one 55-year-old female, who returned from the UK, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
*'''''26 March''''': One male, aged 66 years who was admitted to a private facility in South Kolkata, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web

*'''''27 March''''': One male (aged 11 years) and four females (aged 27 years, 45 years, 6 years and 9 months), all belonging to a close group of siblings and relatives, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> They came in contact with a positive case in Delhi who came from the UK on 16 March.

column1: *'''''28 March''''': Two females, aged 76 years and 56 years who both were kept under quarantine for coming in direct contact with one previously COVID-19 positive case, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> They came in contact with their close relatives who came from the US and Singapore.

column1: *'''''29 March''''': One female of about 44 years who was admitted to a government hospital in [[Kalimpong district
column2: Kalimpong]] on 28 March and had travel history to Thailand and Kerala, was found positive.<ref>{{Cite news
column6: title=এ বার উত্তরবঙ্গে করোনার হানা, আক্রান্ত কালিম্পঙের মহিলা

column1: *'''''30 March''''': The female of 44 years from Kalimpong district expired at a government hospital in [[Siliguri]].<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> Another female of 48 years, who expired at a government hospital in Howrah with a case of Severe Acute Respiratory Illness, was later found COVID-19 positive.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: *'''''31 March''''': One male, who was aged 57 years and had Severe Acute Respiratory Illness, expired at a private facility in Howrah. He was tested positive. Total death count at the end of this month is 4.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus {{!}} Man dies in West Bengal, toll rises to 4

column1: *'''''01 April''''': One male, aged 57 years having [[kidney failure]] and one male, aged 62 years having [[hypertension
column2: high blood pressure]] and other co-morbid conditions, expired early in the morning. Both of them were reportedly tested positive, which is a subject to confirmation.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: State has identified 7 hotspots as of 7 April 2020. The names of hotspots are not officially disclosed. There are rumours that Kolkata, Howrah, Belgharia, Haldia, Egra, Tehatta and Kalimpong are the 7 hotspots.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Seven Covid hotspots identified in Bengal: Mamata Banerjee
column7: title=রাজ্যে মৃত বেড়ে ৫, চিহ্নিত করা এলাকায় তীক্ষ্ণ নজর

column1: *'''''14 March''''': Government on Saturday announced that all schools, colleges and universities in the state will remain closed till 31 March, in the view of evolving situation on the spread of COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Coronavirus {{!}} West Bengal government closes all educational institutions till March 31

column1: *'''''17 March''''': State government stepped up its defence with chief minister [[Mamata Banerjee]] announcing the closure of educational institutions till 15 April. She said that even ICDS would be closed till 15 April and two kilograms of rice and potatoes would be sent to the children directly so that the meals can be cooked at home.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Kolkata schools to remain shut till 15 April: CM

column1: *'''''21 March''''': The government has mandated a partial work-from-home system for 7.9 crore people who get subsidized rations. The CM promised that government will give free ration to the poor till September.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Work-from-home for government staff, free ration for 7.9 crore poor in West Bengal

column1: *'''''23 March''''': West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee announced Monday that the state government is creating a Rs 200 crore fund to deal with the impact of COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Coronavirus lockdown: What states are doing to help the poor and unorganised workers

column1: *'''''24 March''''': Entire West Bengal was brought under lock down till 31 March.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Entire West Bengal brought under lockdown till March 31

column1: *'''''25 March''''': West Bengal Government converts medical college/hospital in isolation for people suspected with coronavirus.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=West Bengal converts state-run hospital in Kolkata into COVID-19 isolation and treatment facility

column1: *'''''30 March''''': West Bengal government issues order to authorities of every districts to set up temporary arrangements of shelter and food to migrants and poor.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Coronavirus Lockdown: West Bengal govt asks districts to set up temporary shelters for poor, migrants

column1: [[Chief Minister of West Bengal]] [[Mamata Banerjee]] and her government was widely criticised of the handling of the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
column2: coronavirus pandemic]] and was accused of concealing facts by the opposition and critics.<ref name=\"FBCOVID\" >{{cite news
column4: quote=Again, on 2 April, while seven coronavirus deaths in the state were confirmed by its health department, the figure was soon revised to three.
column5: title =Coronavirus Outbreak: Mamata Banerjee displays little cooperation even as Opposition unites to stand behind Centre
column11: title =Is hiding Jamaat cases about vote bank: BJP asks Mamata on Bengal coronavirus numbers
column14: quote =The BJP has accused Mamata Banerjee of indulging in vote bank politics after the West Bengal Chief Minister refused to share update on those who attended the Tablighi Jamaat event in Delhi, identified as a hotspot for the spread of novel coronavirus.
column15: publisher =India Today}} </ref> The opposition accused Mamata of playing “appeasement politics” amid the COVID-19 crisis. On 1 April, Banerjee claimed that the [[West Bengal Government]] have already traced 54 people who attended the [[Tablighi Jamaat]] religious gathering during the COVID-19 Outbreak, and 44 of them are foreigners. Although according to a report by central security agencies, 232 people had attended the Delhi's Tablighi Jamaat event from West Bengal. Of this, 123 are Indian nationals and 109 are foreigners.<ref name =\"IndiaTodayCovid\"/><ref name=\"CovidPrint\">{{cite news
column18: title =Mamata calls questions on Tablighi event ‘communal’, avoids giving any answers
column19: quote =West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee Tuesday declined to give an update on the status of the people from the state who had attended Delhi’s Tablighi Jamaat congregation, telling the media to not ask “communal questions”.
column22: accessdate =9 April 2020}} </ref > Sooner she clarified that her government has acted swiftly after the Nizamuddin area was declared as a hotspot where nearly 2,300 people were staying despite the lockdown. She further added that the government has quarantined 177 people, including 108 foreigners, who attended the Tablighi Jamaat congregation at the Nizamuddin Markaz.<ref>{{Cite news
column24: title=Mamata Banerjee reveals Tablighi Jamaat figure: 108 foreigners, 69 other attendees quarantined in West Bengal
column28: title=Tablighi Jamaat case: 108 foreigners, 69 other attendees quarantined in West Bengal

column1: Remaining break up data not available.

As per bulletin of Government of West Bengal, Health & Family Welfare Department website, dated 12 April 2020 <ref>https://www.wbhealth.gov.in/uploaded_files/corona/Bulletin_West_Bengal_12.04_.2020_.pdf</ref> –
* No. of persons under home observation/surveillance: 40576
* No. of persons who have completed surveillance: 15624
* No. of persons admitted under hospital isolation till date: 2085
* No. of persons discharged from hospital isolation till date: 1756
* No. of persons currently admitted in hospital isolation: 329
* No. of samples tested for COVID-19: 2523
* No. of persons expired due to COVID-19: 7
* No. of active COVID-19 cases as of 8 April, 2020: 95

*'''''26 March''''': One male, aged 66 years who was admitted to a private facility in South Kolkata, was tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web

*'''''27 March''''': One male (aged 11 years) and four females (aged 27 years, 45 years, 6 years and 9 months), all belonging to a close group of siblings and relatives, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> They came in contact with a positive case in Delhi who came from the UK on 16 March.

column1: *'''''28 March''''': Two females, aged 76 years and 56 years who both were kept under quarantine for coming in direct contact with one previously COVID-19 positive case, were tested positive.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> They came in contact with their close relatives who came from the US and Singapore.

column1: *'''''29 March''''': One female of about 44 years who was admitted to a government hospital in [[Kalimpong district
column2: Kalimpong]] on 28 March and had travel history to Thailand and Kerala, was found positive.<ref>{{Cite news
column6: title=এ বার উত্তরবঙ্গে করোনার হানা, আক্রান্ত কালিম্পঙের মহিলা

column1: *'''''30 March''''': The female of 44 years from Kalimpong district expired at a government hospital in [[Siliguri]].<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=}}</ref> Another female of 48 years, who expired at a government hospital in Howrah with a case of Severe Acute Respiratory Illness, was later found COVID-19 positive.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: *'''''31 March''''': One male, who was aged 57 years and had Severe Acute Respiratory Illness, expired at a private facility in Howrah. He was tested positive. Total death count at the end of this month is 4.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus {{!}} Man dies in West Bengal, toll rises to 4

column1: *'''''01 April''''': One male, aged 57 years having [[kidney failure]] and one male, aged 62 years having [[hypertension
column2: high blood pressure]] and other co-morbid conditions, expired early in the morning. Both of them were reportedly tested positive, which is a subject to confirmation.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: State has identified 7 hotspots as of 7 April 2020. The names of hotspots are not officially disclosed. There are rumours that Kolkata, Howrah, Belgharia, Haldia, Egra, Tehatta and Kalimpong are the 7 hotspots.<ref>{{Cite news

column5: title=Coronavirus {{!}} West Bengal government closes all educational institutions till March 31

column1: *'''''17 March''''': State government stepped up its defence with chief minister [[Mamata Banerjee]] announcing the closure of educational institutions till 15 April. She said that even ICDS would be closed till 15 April and two kilograms of rice and potatoes would be sent to the children directly so that the meals can be cooked at home.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Kolkata schools to remain shut till 15 April: CM

column1: *'''''21 March''''': The government has mandated a partial work-from-home system for 7.9 crore people who get subsidized rations. The CM promised that government will give free ration to the poor till September.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Work-from-home for government staff, free ration for 7.9 crore poor in West Bengal

column1: *'''''23 March''''': West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee announced Monday that the state government is creating a Rs 200 crore fund to deal with the impact of COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Coronavirus lockdown: What states are doing to help the poor and unorganised workers

column1: *'''''24 March''''': Entire West Bengal was brought under lock down till 31 March.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Entire West Bengal brought under lockdown till March 31

column1: *'''''25 March''''': West Bengal Government converts medical college/hospital in isolation for people suspected with coronavirus.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=West Bengal converts state-run hospital in Kolkata into COVID-19 isolation and treatment facility

column1: *'''''30 March''''': West Bengal government issues order to authorities of every districts to set up temporary arrangements of shelter and food to migrants and poor.<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Coronavirus Lockdown: West Bengal govt asks districts to set up temporary shelters for poor, migrants

column1: [[Chief Minister of West Bengal]] [[Mamata Banerjee]] and her government was widely criticised of the handling of the [[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic
column2: coronavirus pandemic]] and was accused of concealing facts by the opposition and critics.<ref name=\"FBCOVID\" >{{cite news
column4: quote=Again, on 2 April, while seven coronavirus deaths in the state were confirmed by its health department, the figure was soon revised to three.
column5: title =Coronavirus Outbreak: Mamata Banerjee displays little cooperation even as Opposition unites to stand behind Centre
column11: title =Is hiding Jamaat cases about vote bank: BJP asks Mamata on Bengal coronavirus numbers
column14: quote =The BJP has accused Mamata Banerjee of indulging in vote bank politics after the West Bengal Chief Minister refused to share update on those who attended the Tablighi Jamaat event in Delhi, identified as a hotspot for the spread of novel coronavirus.
column15: publisher =India Today}} </ref> The opposition accused Mamata of playing “appeasement politics” amid the COVID-19 crisis. On 1 April, Banerjee claimed that the [[West Bengal Government]] have already traced 54 people who attended the [[Tablighi Jamaat]] religious gathering during the COVID-19 Outbreak, and 44 of them are foreigners. Although according to a report by central security agencies, 232 people had attended the Delhi's Tablighi Jamaat event from West Bengal. Of this, 123 are Indian nationals and 109 are foreigners.<ref name =\"IndiaTodayCovid\"/><ref name=\"CovidPrint\">{{cite news
column18: title =Mamata calls questions on Tablighi event ‘communal’, avoids giving any answers
column19: quote =West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee Tuesday declined to give an update on the status of the people from the state who had attended Delhi’s Tablighi Jamaat congregation, telling the media to not ask “communal questions”.
column22: accessdate =9 April 2020}} </ref > Sooner she clarified that her government has acted swiftly after the Nizamuddin area was declared as a hotspot where nearly 2,300 people were staying despite the lockdown. She further added that the government has quarantined 177 people, including 108 foreigners, who attended the Tablighi Jamaat congregation at the Nizamuddin Markaz.<ref>{{Cite news
column24: title=Mamata Banerjee reveals Tablighi Jamaat figure: 108 foreigners, 69 other attendees quarantined in West Bengal
column28: title=Tablighi Jamaat case: 108 foreigners, 69 other attendees quarantined in West Bengal

→‎Effect of serialization on commercial success,safe,Megaman en m,"{{Use mdy dates

column2: television]] and [[radio program]]ming, a '''serial''' has a continuing plot that unfolds in a sequential episode-by-episode fashion. Serials typically follow main [[story arc]]s that span entire [[television season]]s or even the full run of the series, which distinguishes them from traditional episodic television that relies on more stand-alone episodes. Worldwide, the [[soap opera]] is the most prominent form of serial [[dramatic programming]].

column1: Serials rely on keeping the full nature of the story hidden and revealing elements episode by episode to keep viewers tuning in to learn more. Often these shows employ [[recapping]] segments at the beginning and [[cliffhanger]]s at the end of each episode. Such shows also place a demand on viewers to tune in to every episode to follow the plot.<ref name=\"nyt070724\">{{cite news
column4: title = Smile and Smile and Still Be a Villain
column7: accessdate = February 27, 2009}}</ref> The invention of recording devices such as [[VCR]]s and [[Digital video recorder
column8: DVRs]] has made following this type of show easier, which has resulted in increased success and popularity. Prior to the advent of DVRs, television networks shunned serials in prime time as they made [[broadcast programming]] [[rerun]]s more difficult and television producers shunned them because they were tougher to go into [[broadcast syndication]] years down the road.

column1: Serials contrast with episodic television, with plots relying on a more independent stand-alone format. [[Procedural drama]] television programs are commonly episodic.<ref name=\"NYTimesEpisodic\">{{cite news
Shorter serial programs known as [[telenovela]]s (and earlier, [[radionovela]]s), originating and often produced in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking [[Latin America]], have become popular worldwide.
The term \"serial\" refers to the intrinsic property of a series{{spaced ndash}}namely its [[sequence
column2: order]]. In literature, the term is used as a noun to refer to a format (within a [[genre]]) by which a story is told in contiguous (typically [[chronological]]) installments in sequential issues of a single [[periodical]] publication.

column1: More generally, \"serial\" is applied in [[library and information science]] to materials \"in any medium issued under the same title in a succession of discrete parts, usually numbered (or dated) and appearing at regular or irregular intervals with no predetermined conclusion.\"<ref name=\"Reitz\">Reitz, Joan M. (2004). [http://lu.com/odlis/odlis_s.cfm ''Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science'']. Retrieved March 15, 2006</ref>

The term has been used for a radio or television production with a continuously evolving, unified plot and set of characters, spread over multiple episodes.  In the United States, daytime soap operas have long had a serial structure. Television [[mini-series]] also commonly come in a serial form. Starting in the mid-1970s, series with soap opera-like stories began to be aired in prime time (e.g. ''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)
column3: Dynasty]]''). In the 1990s, shows like ''[[The X-Files]]'' and ''[[The Sopranos]]'' began to use a more serial structure, and now there are a much wider range of shows in serial form.<ref>Jason Mittell. 2015. Complex TV: The Poetics of Contemporary Television Storytelling. NYU Press. {{ISBN

column1: The serial beginning with the advent of

column2: movie serials]] of the early 20th century. With the emergence of television and subsequent decline of the movie-going audience, production of movie serials ceased due to the decreasing revenues. But the serial lived on, moving instead to the small screen and the world of [[Broadcast syndication]] television [[rerun]]s.

column1: The television serial format as known today originated in radio, in the form of children's adventure shows and daily 15-minute programs known as ''soap operas'' (so-called because many of these shows were [[Sponsor (commercial)
column2: sponsored]] by soap companies, such as [[Colgate-Palmolive]] and [[Procter & Gamble]]). Soap operas were specifically engineered to appeal to women (with the intention of increasing sale of soap). They usually ran from Monday through Friday at exactly the same time every day. A show called The Smith Family which ran only one night a week on WENR in Chicago during the early 1930s was credited as the \"great-granddaddy of the soap operas\" by radio historian Francis Chase, Jr. One of the other shows that helped pioneer the daytime soap opera/serial was ''The [[Guiding Light]]'', which debuted on [[NBC]] radio in 1937, and then switched to [[CBS]] Television in 1952. ''The Guiding Light''{{'s}} final episode aired on September 18, 2009, having a total of 15,762 episodes air on CBS. Some of the characters in soap operas have been portrayed as long-suffering (a common theme even in some of today's serials along with the social and economical issues of the day). Children's adventure serials were more like [[film serial]]s, with continuing characters involved in exploits with episodes that often ended in a cliffhanger situation; [[Western (genre)
column3: Westerns]] were a particularly popular format for children's serials on the radio.

column1: ''Guiding Light'' and such other daytime television program serials such as ''[[Search for Tomorrow]]'', ''[[Love of Life]]'', ''[[The Secret Storm]]'', ''[[As the World Turns]]'', ''[[The Edge of Night]]'', ''[[The Doctors (soap opera)
column3: Another World]]'', ''[[Dark Shadows]]'', ''[[One Life to Live]]'', and ''[[All My Children]]'' were popular in the Golden and Silver Ages of television and still are today.

column1: Aside from the social issues, the style and presentation of these shows have changed. Whereas in the 1950s and 1960s the drama was underscored with traditional organ music, and in the 1970s and the 1980s a full orchestra provided the score, the daytime dramas of today use cutting-edged synth-driven music (in a way, music for soaps has come full-circle, from the keyboard to the keyboard).
The nighttime serials are a different story, though the concept is also nothing new. In the 1960s, ABC aired the first real breakthrough nighttime serial, ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)
column2: Peyton Place]]'', inspired by the novel and theatrical film of the same name. After its cancellation, the format went somewhat dormant until Norman Lear produced ''[[Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman]]'' in 1976. In 1977, ABC created another comedy soap (aptly called ''[[Soap (TV series)
column3: Soap]]''). Although the show was controversial for its time (with a homosexual character among its cast roster), it was (and still is today) a cult classic.

column2: Dallas]]'' popularized serial storylines on prime-time television. Its end-of-season [[cliffhanger]]s, such as \"[[Who shot J. R.?]]\" and \"Bobby in the Shower?\",<ref name=\"marshall201810\">{{Cite magazine
column6: title=‘Dallas’ at 40: The Inside Story Behind the Show That Changed Texas Forever
column10: access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> influenced other shows like ''[[Dynasty (1981 TV series)
column11: Dynasty]]'' (ABC's answer to ''Dallas''), ''[[Knots Landing]]'', ''[[Falcon Crest]]'', ''[[The Colbys]]'', ''[[Flamingo Road (TV series)
column13: Hotel]]'', ''[[The Yellow Rose]]'', ''[[Bare Essence]]'', and ''[[Berrenger's]]''. There were some serial shows such as ''[[Hill Street Blues]]'' and ''[[St. Elsewhere]]'' that did not officially fit into this category, but were nonetheless ratings hits season after season.

column1: While the last of the 1980s nighttime soaps ended during the first years of the following decade, then a second wave came with series like ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'', ''[[Melrose Place]]'', ''[[Models, Inc.]]'', ''[[Savannah (TV series)
column3: Central Park West]]''. But as the 1990s came to a close, the primetime soap as an official format gradually faded away, where it largely seems to remain as of the middle of the first decade of the 21st century in the United States.

column1: Serialized storytelling can also be seen in other dramas. Heavily serialized dramas include  '' [[Star Trek Deep Space Nine]]'', ''[[Babylon 5]]'', ''[[The Sopranos]]'', ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', ''[[24 (TV series)
column4: Dexter]]'', ''[[The Wire]]'', and ''[[Downton Abbey]]''. Series such as ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', ''[[Veronica Mars]]'', ''[[Homicide: Life on the Streets]]'', ''[[The Good Wife]]'', and ''[[The X-Files]]'' fall somewhere in-between, featuring a new case each week that is solved by the end of the episode, but also having an overarching mystery that receives focus in many episodes. The more serialized its storytelling, the less likely a show is to fare well in repeats. The format places a demand on episodes to be run in order, without which story arcs stretching over many episodes may be difficult for new viewers to delve into. ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'' also falls into the category while each season involves a new mystery that spans an entire season (and on one occasion, half the season) while planting hints throughout the episodes until the climax in the finale.

column1: To a lesser extent, series such as ''[[House (TV series)
column8: accessdate = February 12, 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"procedural at its core\">{{cite news
column11: title = Ask Ausiello: Spoilers on 'Grey's,' 'House,' 'Big Love,' 'Fringe,' 'NCIS,' '24,' 'Gossip Girl,' 'Friday Night Lights,' 'Heroes,' 'Smallville,' and more!
column21: title = JJ Abrams live webchat here
column27: last=Holmwood}}</ref> may also feature ongoing story arcs, but episodes are more self-encapsulated and so the series fall into a more conventional drama category. ''Fringe'' has experimented with \"myth-alones\", a hybrid that attempts to advance the story arc in a self-contained episode.<ref name=\"comiccon\"/>

column1: In addition, it has been noted that the use of [[cliffhanger]]s is still prevalent in adventure shows; however, they are now typically used just before a commercial break and the viewer need only wait a few minutes to see its resolution. In addition, many series have also made extensive use of the traditional end-of-episode cliffhanger format. This is most common in [[season finale]]s which often end in a cliffhanger that would only be resolved in the next season's premiere.

Over the course of its run, a show may change its focus. Matt Cherniss, executive vice president of programming at Fox says: \"Sometimes early on, being a little more episodic allows more people into the room. And as the show goes on, by its nature, it might find itself becoming a little more serialized.\"<ref name=\"ct090227\">{{cite news
column4: title = Has TV lost its nerve when it comes to complex dramas?
column7: accessdate = February 27, 2009}}</ref> Early in their runs, shows such as ''[[Lost (TV series)
column13: title = Buffy's creator makes his valley of the dolls
column17: accessdate = May 16, 2009 }}</ref> and ''[[Torchwood]]'' put greater emphasis on the \"story-of-the-week\", but over time story arcs begin to dominate. In contrast, ''[[Alias (TV series)
column18: Alias]]'' became more focused on standalone stories in later seasons, because of pressures by network executives.<ref name=\"fringe\"/>

column1: == Effect of serialization on commercial success ==

Complex [[story arc]]s may have a negative effect on ratings by making entry more difficult for new viewers as well as confusing fans who have missed an episode.<ref name=\"guardian\"/> Networks see them as riskier than dramas that focus on a self-contained story of the week.<ref name=\"risky\">{{cite news
column4: title = Q&A: Ron Moore on 'Battlestar' series finale
column7: accessdate = March 13, 2009}}</ref> Tom O'Neil of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' notes: \"They're chancy because these shows are hard to join midway through.\"<ref name=\"gd080921\">{{cite news
column10: title = TRANSCRIPT: The Envelope chat with Glenn Close
column14: 2012}} CBS has not aired a serial drama in many years, in part because of the success of its non-serial [[procedural (genre)
column17: title=As Talent Flees to Cable, Networks Fight Back

column1: Scott Collins of the ''Los Angeles Times'' stated that \"serialized storytelling ... though popular with hard-core fans and many critics, requires more dedication from viewers and has almost certainly tamped down ratings for many shows\". He quoted an ad executive who states that close-ended story lines \"[make] it easier for new viewers to tune in and figure out what's going on\".<ref name=\"cbssucess\">{{cite news
column4: title = How does CBS spell success? 'NCIS'
column7: accessdate = February 12, 2009}}</ref> According to [[Dick Wolf]], serialized elements also make it more difficult for viewers to return to a show if they have missed some episodes.<ref name=\"guardian\">{{cite news
column16: accessdate = February 20, 2009}}</ref> ''[[Cheers]]'' co-creator [[Les Charles]] regrets helping to make serialization common: \"[W]e may have been partly responsible for what's going on now, where if you miss the first episode or two, you are lost. You have to wait until you can get the whole thing on DVD and catch up with it. If that blood is on our hands, I feel kind of badly about it. It can be very frustrating.\"<ref name=\"gqraftery201210\">{{cite news
column18: title=The Best TV Show That's Ever Been

column1: Another problem is that many fans prefer to record these shows and [[binge-watching
column2: binge watch]] the whole season in one session.<ref name=\"gd080921\"/> These viewers are not included in TV ratings as they are much less likely to watch commercials than live viewers. The move away from live viewing and toward DVR or internet-streaming services has hurt many shows' prospects because there are fewer or no commercials and they may be fast-forwarded or out-of-date.<ref name=\"decline\">{{cite news
column5: title = A dramatic decline for network dramas

column1: Concerned about the toll on ratings of complex story arcs, networks sometimes ask showrunners to reduce serialization. Network executives believe that standalone episodes serve as a better jumping on point for new viewers, although this may result in a conflict with regular watchers who tend to prefer more focus on story arcs.<ref name=\"comiccon\">{{cite news

column2: Alias]]'' began as a more serialized show but later became more stand-alone under network pressure.<ref name=\"fringe\"/> During season 3 of the re-imagined ''[[Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)
column3: Battlestar Galactica]]'', showrunner [[Ronald D. Moore]] was also pressured to make episodes more stand-alone. This move resulted in negative criticism from both fans and critics, and Moore revealed in the Season 3 finale podcast that the network finally accepted that standalone episodes simply do not work for the story he is trying to tell.<ref>[http://www.scifi.com/battlestar/downloads/podcast.php?seas=3 ] {{webarchive

column1: Moore has also stated that the network was reluctant to greenlight ''[[Caprica (TV series)
column2: Caprica]]'' mainly because story-arc-heavy series notoriously have difficulty in picking up new viewers, as compared to a series composed of mostly standalone episodes.<ref>''Battlestar Galactica Season 3 Companion''</ref>

column1: According to [[Todd A. Kessler]], the second season of ''[[Damages (TV series)
column2: Damages]]'' will be less serialized in order to render the show more accessible to new viewers.<ref name=\"variety080616\">{{cite news

Heroes]]'', has also suggested that his show may move away from serialized storytelling: \"I think the show needs to move towards [standalone episodes] in order to survive.\"<ref name=\"ign081117\">{{cite news
column5: title = Could Heroes Move Away From Serialization?

column1: Networks also discourage complex story arcs because they are less successful in reruns, and because standalone episodes can be rerun without concern for order.<ref name=\"thrfeedwhedon\">{{cite news

column4: title = This Was the Year That TV's Second Golden Age Ended

column1: and ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''<ref name=\"ct090227\"/> have expressed concern that declining ratings may lead to a major reduction in serialized storytelling. To highlight the situation, in the 2006–2007 season, no fewer than five high-concept serials were introduced, including ''[[Jericho (2006 TV series)
column5: Drive]]'', all of which experienced fairly quick cancellation due to low ratings.<ref name=\"starnews070524\">{{cite news

column1: In 2010 and 2011, more high-profile, high-cost serials failed to achieve success, including ''[[V (2009 TV series)

Some reviewers have also noted that serialized dramas are at a disadvantage at major awards shows such as the [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s. Such shows generally have to submit an atypical self-contained episode in order to gain recognition.<ref name=\"la080819\">{{cite news
column4: title = Early, gutsy Emmy predix: 'Mad Men' vs. 'Damages'

column1: Despite this, since 2000, every winner of the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series]] has been a Serial Drama: ''[[The West Wing]]'' (2000–2003), ''[[The Sopranos]]'' (2004, 2007), ''[[Lost (TV series)
column4: Homeland]]'' (2012), ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' (2013–2014), ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' (2015-2016), and ''[[The Handmaid's Tale]]'' (2017).

column1: In terms of DVD sales, however, strongly serialized shows often perform better than shows which are strongly procedural. ''[[24 (TV series)

column4: title=US DVD Sales Chart for Week Ending Jan 18, 2009

column1: Serialized shows tend to develop a more dedicated fanbase interested in exploring the show online as well as becoming customers of additional merchandising.<ref name=\"risky\"/>

column2: television]] and [[radio program]]ming, a '''serial''' has a continuing plot that unfolds in a sequential episode-by-episode fashion. Serials typically follow main [[story arc]]s that span entire [[television season]]s or even the full run of the series, which distinguishes them from traditional episodic television that relies on more stand-alone episodes. Worldwide, the [[soap opera]] is the most prominent form of serial [[dramatic programming]].

column1: Serials rely on keeping the full nature of the story hidden and revealing elements episode by episode to keep viewers tuning in to learn more. Often these shows employ [[recapping]] segments at the beginning and [[cliffhanger]]s at the end of each episode. Such shows also place a demand on viewers to tune in to every episode to follow the plot.<ref name=\"nyt070724\">{{cite news
column4: title = Smile and Smile and Still Be a Villain
column7: accessdate = February 27, 2009}}</ref> The invention of recording devices such as [[VCR]]s and [[Digital video recorder
column8: DVRs]] has made following this type of show easier, which has resulted in increased success and popularity. Prior to the advent of DVRs, television networks shunned serials in prime time as they made [[broadcast programming]] [[rerun]]s more difficult and television producers shunned them because they were tougher to go into [[broadcast syndication]] years down the road.

column1: Serials contrast with episodic television, with plots relying on a more independent stand-alone format. [[Procedural drama]] television programs are commonly episodic.<ref name=\"NYTimesEpisodic\">{{cite news
Shorter serial programs known as [[telenovela]]s (and earlier, [[radionovela]]s), originating and often produced in Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking [[Latin America]], have become popular worldwide.
The term \"serial\" refers to the intrinsic property of a series{{spaced ndash}}namely its [[sequence
column2: order]]. In literature, the term is used as a noun to refer to a format (within a [[genre]]) by which a story is told in contiguous (typically [[chronological]]) installments in sequential issues of a single [[periodical]] publication.

column1: More generally, \"serial\" is applied in [[library and information science]] to materials \"in any medium issued under the same title in a succession of discrete parts, usually numbered (or dated) and appearing at regular or irregular intervals with no predetermined conclusion.\"<ref name=\"Reitz\">Reitz, Joan M. (2004). [http://lu.com/odlis/odlis_s.cfm ''Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science'']. Retrieved March 15, 2006</ref>

The term has been used for a radio or television production with a continuously evolving, unified plot and set of characters, spread over multiple episodes.  In the United States, daytime soap operas have long had a serial structure. Television [[mini-series]] also commonly come in a serial form. Starting in the mid-1970s, series with soap opera-like stories began to be aired in prime time (e.g. ''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)
column3: Dynasty]]''). In the 1990s, shows like ''[[The X-Files]]'' and ''[[The Sopranos]]'' began to use a more serial structure, and now there are a much wider range of shows in serial form.<ref>Jason Mittell. 2015. Complex TV: The Poetics of Contemporary Television Storytelling. NYU Press. {{ISBN

column1: The serial beginning with the advent of

column2: movie serials]] of the early 20th century. With the emergence of television and subsequent decline of the movie-going audience, production of movie serials ceased due to the decreasing revenues. But the serial lived on, moving instead to the small screen and the world of [[Broadcast syndication]] television [[rerun]]s.

column1: The television serial format as known today originated in radio, in the form of children's adventure shows and daily 15-minute programs known as ''soap operas'' (so-called because many of these shows were [[Sponsor (commercial)
column2: sponsored]] by soap companies, such as [[Colgate-Palmolive]] and [[Procter & Gamble]]). Soap operas were specifically engineered to appeal to women (with the intention of increasing sale of soap). They usually ran from Monday through Friday at exactly the same time every day. A show called The Smith Family which ran only one night a week on WENR in Chicago during the early 1930s was credited as the \"great-granddaddy of the soap operas\" by radio historian Francis Chase, Jr. One of the other shows that helped pioneer the daytime soap opera/serial was ''The [[Guiding Light]]'', which debuted on [[NBC]] radio in 1937, and then switched to [[CBS]] Television in 1952. ''The Guiding Light''{{'s}} final episode aired on September 18, 2009, having a total of 15,762 episodes air on CBS. Some of the characters in soap operas have been portrayed as long-suffering (a common theme even in some of today's serials along with the social and economical issues of the day). Children's adventure serials were more like [[film serial]]s, with continuing characters involved in exploits with episodes that often ended in a cliffhanger situation; [[Western (genre)
column3: Westerns]] were a particularly popular format for children's serials on the radio.

column1: ''Guiding Light'' and such other daytime television program serials such as ''[[Search for Tomorrow]]'', ''[[Love of Life]]'', ''[[The Secret Storm]]'', ''[[As the World Turns]]'', ''[[The Edge of Night]]'', ''[[The Doctors (soap opera)
column3: Another World]]'', ''[[Dark Shadows]]'', ''[[One Life to Live]]'', and ''[[All My Children]]'' were popular in the Golden and Silver Ages of television and still are today.

column1: Aside from the social issues, the style and presentation of these shows have changed. Whereas in the 1950s and 1960s the drama was underscored with traditional organ music, and in the 1970s and the 1980s a full orchestra provided the score, the daytime dramas of today use cutting-edged synth-driven music (in a way, music for soaps has come full-circle, from the keyboard to the keyboard).
The nighttime serials are a different story, though the concept is also nothing new. In the 1960s, ABC aired the first real breakthrough nighttime serial, ''[[Peyton Place (TV series)
column2: Peyton Place]]'', inspired by the novel and theatrical film of the same name. After its cancellation, the format went somewhat dormant until Norman Lear produced ''[[Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman]]'' in 1976. In 1977, ABC created another comedy soap (aptly called ''[[Soap (TV series)
column3: Soap]]''). Although the show was controversial for its time (with a homosexual character among its cast roster), it was (and still is today) a cult classic.

column2: Dallas]]'' popularized serial storylines on prime-time television. Its end-of-season [[cliffhanger]]s, such as \"[[Who shot J. R.?]]\" and \"Bobby in the Shower?\",<ref name=\"marshall201810\">{{Cite magazine
column6: title=‘Dallas’ at 40: The Inside Story Behind the Show That Changed Texas Forever
column10: access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> influenced other shows like ''[[Dynasty (1981 TV series)
column11: Dynasty]]'' (ABC's answer to ''Dallas''), ''[[Knots Landing]]'', ''[[Falcon Crest]]'', ''[[The Colbys]]'', ''[[Flamingo Road (TV series)
column13: Hotel]]'', ''[[The Yellow Rose]]'', ''[[Bare Essence]]'', and ''[[Berrenger's]]''. There were some serial shows such as ''[[Hill Street Blues]]'' and ''[[St. Elsewhere]]'' that did not officially fit into this category, but were nonetheless ratings hits season after season.

column1: While the last of the 1980s nighttime soaps ended during the first years of the following decade, then a second wave came with series like ''[[Beverly Hills, 90210]]'', ''[[Melrose Place]]'', ''[[Models, Inc.]]'', ''[[Savannah (TV series)
column3: Central Park West]]''. But as the 1990s came to a close, the primetime soap as an official format gradually faded away, where it largely seems to remain as of the middle of the first decade of the 21st century in the United States.

column1: Serialized storytelling can also be seen in other dramas. Heavily serialized dramas include  '' [[Star Trek Deep Space Nine]]'', ''[[Babylon 5]]'', ''[[The Sopranos]]'', ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', ''[[24 (TV series)
column4: Dexter]]'', ''[[The Wire]]'', and ''[[Downton Abbey]]''. Series such as ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', ''[[Veronica Mars]]'', ''[[Homicide: Life on the Streets]]'', ''[[The Good Wife]]'', and ''[[The X-Files]]'' fall somewhere in-between, featuring a new case each week that is solved by the end of the episode, but also having an overarching mystery that receives focus in many episodes. The more serialized its storytelling, the less likely a show is to fare well in repeats. The format places a demand on episodes to be run in order, without which story arcs stretching over many episodes may be difficult for new viewers to delve into. ''[[Desperate Housewives]]'' also falls into the category while each season involves a new mystery that spans an entire season (and on one occasion, half the season) while planting hints throughout the episodes until the climax in the finale.

column1: To a lesser extent, series such as ''[[House (TV series)
column8: accessdate = February 12, 2009}}</ref><ref name=\"procedural at its core\">{{cite news
column11: title = Ask Ausiello: Spoilers on 'Grey's,' 'House,' 'Big Love,' 'Fringe,' 'NCIS,' '24,' 'Gossip Girl,' 'Friday Night Lights,' 'Heroes,' 'Smallville,' and more!
column21: title = JJ Abrams live webchat here
column27: last=Holmwood}}</ref> may also feature ongoing story arcs, but episodes are more self-encapsulated and so the series fall into a more conventional drama category. ''Fringe'' has experimented with \"myth-alones\", a hybrid that attempts to advance the story arc in a self-contained episode.<ref name=\"comiccon\"/>

column1: In addition, it has been noted that the use of [[cliffhanger]]s is still prevalent in adventure shows; however, they are now typically used just before a commercial break and the viewer need only wait a few minutes to see its resolution. In addition, many series have also made extensive use of the traditional end-of-episode cliffhanger format. This is most common in [[season finale]]s which often end in a cliffhanger that would only be resolved in the next season's premiere.

Over the course of its run, a show may change its focus. Matt Cherniss, executive vice president of programming at Fox says: \"Sometimes early on, being a little more episodic allows more people into the room. And as the show goes on, by its nature, it might find itself becoming a little more serialized.\"<ref name=\"ct090227\">{{cite news
column4: title = Has TV lost its nerve when it comes to complex dramas?
column7: accessdate = February 27, 2009}}</ref> Early in their runs, shows such as ''[[Lost (TV series)
column13: title = Buffy's creator makes his valley of the dolls
column17: accessdate = May 16, 2009 }}</ref> and ''[[Torchwood]]'' put greater emphasis on the \"story-of-the-week\", but over time story arcs begin to dominate. In contrast, ''[[Alias (TV series)
column18: Alias]]'' became more focused on standalone stories in later seasons, because of pressures by network executives.<ref name=\"fringe\"/>

column1: == Effect of serialization on commercial success ==

Complex [[story arc]]s may have a negative effect on ratings by making entry more difficult for new viewers as well as confusing fans who have missed an episode.<ref name=\"guardian\"/> Networks see them as riskier than dramas that focus on a self-contained story of the week.<ref name=\"risky\">{{cite news
column4: title = Q&A: Ron Moore on 'Battlestar' series finale
column7: accessdate = March 13, 2009}}</ref> Tom O'Neil of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' notes: \"They're chancy because these shows are hard to join midway through.\"<ref name=\"gd080921\">{{cite news
column10: title = TRANSCRIPT: The Envelope chat with Glenn Close
column14: 2012}} CBS has not aired a serial drama in many years, in part because of the success of its non-serial [[procedural (genre)
column17: title=As Talent Flees to Cable, Networks Fight Back

column1: Scott Collins of the ''Los Angeles Times'' stated that \"serialized storytelling ... though popular with hard-core fans and many critics, requires more dedication from viewers and has almost certainly tamped down ratings for many shows\". He quoted an ad executive who states that close-ended story lines \"[make] it easier for new viewers to tune in and figure out what's going on\".<ref name=\"cbssucess\">{{cite news
column4: title = How does CBS spell success? 'NCIS'
column7: accessdate = February 12, 2009}}</ref> According to [[Dick Wolf]], serialized elements also make it more difficult for viewers to return to a show if they have missed some episodes.<ref name=\"guardian\">{{cite news
column16: accessdate = February 20, 2009}}</ref> ''[[Cheers]]'' co-creator [[Les Charles]] regrets helping to make serialization common: \"[W]e may have been partly responsible for what's going on now, where if you miss the first episode or two, you are lost. You have to wait until you can get the whole thing on DVD and catch up with it. If that blood is on our hands, I feel kind of badly about it. It can be very frustrating.\"<ref name=\"gqraftery201210\">{{cite news
column18: title=The Best TV Show That's Ever Been

column1: Another problem is that many fans prefer to record these shows and [[binge-watching
column2: binge watch]] the whole season in one session.<ref name=\"gd080921\"/> These viewers are not included in TV ratings as they are much less likely to watch commercials than live viewers. The move away from live viewing and toward DVR or internet-streaming services has hurt many shows' prospects because there are fewer or no commercials and they may be fast-forwarded or out-of-date.<ref name=\"decline\">{{cite news
column5: title = A dramatic decline for network dramas

column1: Concerned about the toll on ratings of complex story arcs, networks sometimes ask showrunners to reduce serialization. Network executives believe that standalone episodes serve as a better jumping on point for new viewers, although this may result in a conflict with regular watchers who tend to prefer more focus on story arcs.<ref name=\"comiccon\">{{cite news

column2: Alias]]'' began as a more serialized show but later became more stand-alone under network pressure.<ref name=\"fringe\"/> During season 3 of the re-imagined ''[[Battlestar Galactica (2004 TV series)
column3: Battlestar Galactica]]'', showrunner [[Ronald D. Moore]] was also pressured to make episodes more stand-alone. This move resulted in negative criticism from both fans and critics, and Moore revealed in the Season 3 finale podcast that the network finally accepted that standalone episodes simply do not work for the story he is trying to tell.<ref>[http://www.scifi.com/battlestar/downloads/podcast.php?seas=3 ] {{webarchive

column1: Moore has also stated that the network was reluctant to greenlight ''[[Caprica (TV series)
column2: Caprica]]'' mainly because story-arc-heavy series notoriously have difficulty in picking up new viewers, as compared to a series composed of mostly standalone episodes.<ref>''Battlestar Galactica Season 3 Companion''</ref>

column1: According to [[Todd A. Kessler]], the second season of ''[[Damages (TV series)
column2: Damages]]'' will be less serialized in order to render the show more accessible to new viewers.<ref name=\"variety080616\">{{cite news

Heroes]]'', has also suggested that his show may move away from serialized storytelling: \"I think the show needs to move towards [standalone episodes] in order to survive.\"<ref name=\"ign081117\">{{cite news
column5: title = Could Heroes Move Away From Serialization?

column1: Networks also discourage complex story arcs because they are less successful in reruns, and because standalone episodes can be rerun without concern for order.<ref name=\"thrfeedwhedon\">{{cite news

column4: title = This Was the Year That TV's Second Golden Age Ended

column1: and ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''<ref name=\"ct090227\"/> have expressed concern that declining ratings may lead to a major reduction in serialized storytelling. To highlight the situation, in the 2006–2007 season, no fewer than five high-concept serials were introduced, including ''[[Jericho (2006 TV series)
column5: Drive]]'', all of which experienced fairly quick cancellation due to low ratings.<ref name=\"starnews070524\">{{cite news

column1: In 2010 and 2011, more high-profile, high-cost serials failed to achieve success, including ''[[V (2009 TV series)

Some reviewers have also noted that serialized dramas are at a disadvantage at major awards shows such as the [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s. Such shows generally have to submit an atypical self-contained episode in order to gain recognition.<ref name=\"la080819\">{{cite news
column4: title = Early, gutsy Emmy predix: 'Mad Men' vs. 'Damages'

column1: Despite this, since 2000, every winner of the [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series]] has been a [[Serial (radio and television)#Popular serial dramas
column2: Serial Drama]]: ''[[The West Wing]]'' (2000–2003), ''[[The Sopranos]]'' (2004, 2007), ''[[Lost (TV series)
column5: Homeland]]'' (2012), ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' (2013–2014), ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' (2015-2016), and ''[[The Handmaid's Tale]]'' (2017).

column1: Serialized shows tend to develop a more dedicated fanbase interested in exploring the show online as well as becoming customers of additional merchandising.<ref name=\"risky\"/>

column1: '''Yang Joon-il''' (born 19 August 1969), also known as '''Joon-il Yang''', '''JIY''' and '''V2''', is a Korean-American singer-songwriter. Nicknamed the \"G-Dragon of the 1990s\", Yang made his debut in 1991 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". He was active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993 before he was banned to perform on TV. He fled back to America disappearing away from the public scene. He recently gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=50歲韓歌手撞樣 封「90年代GD」引關注
column8: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column22: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene
column26: date=31 December 2019 }}</ref> As of 2020, he is active in various fields such as fan meeting, book writing, public appearances, lectures, commercials, beauty and fashion related activities.

column1: Yang was born in [[Vietnam]] during the [[Vietnam War
column2: war]] in 1969 and spent his childhood in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref> Yang emigrated to the [[United States]] with his family at age nine and grew up in [[Los Angeles]]. After one year of dating Yang married a woman who fell in love at first sight in 2006 and the first son was born in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=양준일…아내와 인연, 결혼 이유 첫 고백 “한눈에 반했다”

column1: When he was in [[Glendale High School (Glendale, California)
column2: Glendale High School]] in LA, he was persuaded to make a debut as an entertainer by the late Hollywood actor [[Soon-Tek Oh
column3: Soon-tek Oh]], who was a member to the same church.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=故 오순택 누구?...양준일과 미국서 깊은 인연 {{!}} 텐아시아
column11: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang was a soloist in his high school choir. He took classes at [https://www.jrpowersphilly.com/ John Robert Powers Modeling, Acting Agency & Finishing School] in [[Philadelphia]] to prepare for his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=‘배철수 잼’ 양준일, 발라드 가수 데뷔 비하인드...‘리베카’ 어쿠스틱 버전 공개[종합]

column1: He entered [[University of Southern California]] [[USC Marshall School of Business
column4: title=[코리아타임스 뉴스] 시간여행자 양준일, 30년이 지나서야 인정받다
column8: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> During his studies, he was selected by Lee Beom-hee, who was the famous composer of the day.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=양준일 리베카 신드롬 열풍 “역주행 아이콘 양준일 누구?”
column14: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang dropped out to debut as a singer in Korea in 1990.

column1: Yang debuted in 1991 at the age of 22 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". \"Rebecca\" and \"Help me Cupid!\" were performed on the air, but not a big hit. His 2nd full length album was released in 1992. He released other hit songs like \"Dance with Me Miss\" (1992) and \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\" (1992).<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /><ref name=\"koreajoongangdaily\" /><ref name=\"yonhap\" />
He was credited as the first pop musician to introduce Korean audiences to the [[new jack swing]] genre, which was popular in the mid-1980s and early 1990s in the U.S.

Active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993, he suddenly disappeared from the public scene and returned to the U.S. In a 2019 interview with the [[The Korea Times]], he revealed that \"he was hated by many for his unusual looks and songs.\" Some also threw rocks during his performance at an open-air stage. While a 10-year visa he held in Korea as a U.S. national had to be recertified every six months, he was denied an extension to his visa for no reason by an official at the Immigration Office. His nationality as an American also made it hard for him to gain acceptance in South Korea.

In 2001, he made another debut as JIY, a member of a music band V2, with a third album \"Fantasy\". V2 meant his \"Version 2\". He was in active under the name of JIY instead of his real name, Yang Joon-il. He lied about his age and made a big change in his look.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='배철수 잼' 양준일, 험난했던 인생사→신드롬에 대한 솔직 고백까지(종합)
column7: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> He hid his true identity as music producers told him he would not make it again due to his previous controversial image in Korea. His new song \"Fantasy\", composed by Valery Gaina of [[Cruise (band)
column8: Cruise]], enjoyed a brief popularity before he finally put an end to his music career. Due to the agency's circumstances, it became impossible to work as a musician and after that he worked as an English teacher for 14 years.  In 2015, he returned to the United States. Because of his age, he had a hard time finding work. He worked as a warehouse worker, office cleaner, and restaurant server.

column1: In 2019, he gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past. He sang \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGIndlf_xU4&t=64s Rebecca]\", [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QU462sGMclc \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\", \"Dance With Me Miss\"], and \"Fantasy\". Still slim in figure and soulful in his performance, he dazzled the audience and show hosts.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column7: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> When asked his next plans amid this viral syndrome, he simply said: \"I don't make any plans; I just focus on fully living every moment. If there's any plans, I hope to live as a humble husband and dad.\" When the show hosts asked him to give a message to 20-year-old himself living 30 years ago, Yang said: \"I know nothing will happen how you want. But don't worry, everything will come out perfectly in the end.\"<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /> After his fame skyrocketed again after his appearance on the show, he quit his job at the restaurant to focus on his entertainment career.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title='G-Dragon of the 90s' Yang Joon Il visits JTBC's 'News Room' after his surging popularity, says he was working at a restaurant in Florida

column1: On December 25, Christmas Day, he appeared on [[JTBC Newsroom]]. He said \"It's like a dream every day\", \"I've been trying to get rid of my prejudice against myself, which is full of my mind as if I had to abandon my unhappiness before I was happy.\"  \"There are no more tears\" Yang said, adding that his powerful fandom, which claims to be a support group, is also a big boost to Yang.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Celebrity of celebrity, Yang Joon-il Syndrome in Korea {{!}} HaB Korea.net

column1: On December 31, Yang met with fans through two official fan meeting events. \"Are you really here to see me?\"he said, tearing up with joy. \"This is my first time. I didn't imagine any of this. I'm so grateful.\"<ref name=\":1\" />  In a press conference at a fan meeting, he revealed that his sole dream of becoming a K-pop star in his 20s was finally accomplished now, at age 50.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene

column1: Just a few days before the fan meeting he shot a commercial with Lotte Home Shopping<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='GD of the 90's Yang Joon Il lands a Lotte Home Shopping CF
column5: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> for the first time in his life. He spent that money to rent an apartment in Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=‘해투4’ 양준일 “생애 첫 광고모델료 받아 韓아파트 보증금 마련”

column1: On January 3 in 2020, Yang created his account on [[Instagram]].[https://www.instagram.com/jiytime/?hl=ko jiytime] On the 4th, he performed his debut song \"Rebecca\" on [[MBC TV
column2: MBC]]'s \"[[Show! Music Core]]\" after 28 years after his debut.<ref>{{Cite web

The title of the program is meant to commemorate his debut year, 1991 and 2019 when he was recovered.<ref>{{Cite web

column1: On Febraury 3, his photo essay [Yang Joon Il Maybe] started a pre-sale. On the first day, over 15,000 copies were pre-sold and it became bestseller. A series of the interviews with the behind-the-scenes of photo shooting for his book was released also.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C3qzBsWHvic interview-Question From Yang Joon Il] On the 9th, Yang opened his official YouTube channel, [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWagJUPy0iR5Cf8hafiYM-w Official Yang Joon Il]. The number of subscribers has spiked up to over 15K in a single day.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon Il opens up his official YouTube channel!
column5: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> On Valentine's day, on Febraury 14, [Yang Joon Il Maybe] was officially released.

column1: He also plans to re-arrange and re-record his old songs to release a repackaged album. After that, he hopes to release new songs.

column1: '''Yang Joon-il''' (born 19 August 1969), also known as '''Joon-il Yang''', '''JIY''' and '''V2''', is a Korean-American singer-songwriter. Nicknamed the \"G-Dragon of the 1990s\", Yang made his debut in 1991 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". He was active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993 before he was banned to perform on TV. He fled back to America disappearing away from the public scene. He recently gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=50歲韓歌手撞樣 封「90年代GD」引關注
column8: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column22: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene
column26: date=31 December 2019 }}</ref> As of 2020, he is active in various fields such as fan meeting, book writing, public appearances, lectures, commercials, beauty and fashion related activities.

column1: Yang was born in [[Vietnam]] during the [[Vietnam War
column2: war]] in 1969 and spent his childhood in Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: access-date=2020-03-28}}</ref> Yang emigrated to the [[United States]] with his family at age nine and grew up in [[Los Angeles]]. After one year of dating Yang married a woman who fell in love at first sight in 2006 and the first son was born in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=양준일…아내와 인연, 결혼 이유 첫 고백 “한눈에 반했다”

column1: When he was in [[Glendale High School (Glendale, California)
column2: Glendale High School]] in LA, he was persuaded to make a debut as an entertainer by the late Hollywood actor [[Soon-Tek Oh
column3: Soon-tek Oh]], who was a member to the same church.<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=故 오순택 누구?...양준일과 미국서 깊은 인연 {{!}} 텐아시아
column11: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang was a soloist in his high school choir. He took classes at [https://www.jrpowersphilly.com/ John Robert Powers Modeling, Acting Agency & Finishing School] in [[Philadelphia]] to prepare for his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: title=‘배철수 잼’ 양준일, 발라드 가수 데뷔 비하인드...‘리베카’ 어쿠스틱 버전 공개[종합]

column1: He entered [[University of Southern California]] [[USC Marshall School of Business
column4: title=[코리아타임스 뉴스] 시간여행자 양준일, 30년이 지나서야 인정받다
column8: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> During his studies, he was selected by Lee Beom-hee, who was the famous composer of the day.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=양준일 리베카 신드롬 열풍 “역주행 아이콘 양준일 누구?”
column14: access-date=2020-04-06}}</ref> Yang dropped out to debut as a singer in Korea in 1990.

column1: Yang debuted in 1991 at the age of 22 with a song titled \"Rebecca\". \"Rebecca\" and \"Help me Cupid!\" were performed on the air, but not a big hit. His 2nd full length album was released in 1992. He released other hit songs like \"Dance with Me Miss\" (1992) and \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\" (1992).<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /><ref name=\"koreajoongangdaily\" /><ref name=\"yonhap\" />
He was credited as the first pop musician to introduce Korean audiences to the [[new jack swing]] genre, which was popular in the mid-1980s and early 1990s in the U.S.

Active in South Korea from 1991 to 1993, he suddenly disappeared from the public scene and returned to the U.S. In a 2019 interview with the [[The Korea Times]], he revealed that \"he was hated by many for his unusual looks and songs.\" Some also threw rocks during his performance at an open-air stage. While a 10-year visa he held in Korea as a U.S. national had to be recertified every six months, he was denied an extension to his visa for no reason by an official at the Immigration Office. His nationality as an American also made it hard for him to gain acceptance in South Korea.

In 2001, he made another debut as JIY, a member of a music band V2, with a third album \"Fantasy\". V2 meant his \"Version 2\". He was in active under the name of JIY instead of his real name, Yang Joon-il. He lied about his age and made a big change in his look.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='배철수 잼' 양준일, 험난했던 인생사→신드롬에 대한 솔직 고백까지(종합)
column7: access-date=2020-04-08}}</ref> He hid his true identity as music producers told him he would not make it again due to his previous controversial image in Korea. His new song \"Fantasy\", composed by Valery Gaina of [[Cruise (band)
column8: Cruise]], enjoyed a brief popularity before he finally put an end to his music career. Due to the agency's circumstances, it became impossible to work as a musician and after that he worked as an English teacher for 14 years.  In 2015, he returned to the United States. Because of his age, he had a hard time finding work. He worked as a warehouse worker, office cleaner, and restaurant server.

column1: In 2019, he gained attention through [[JTBC]]'s ''[[Two Yoo Project Sugar Man]]'', a program dedicated to finding and rediscovering old singers from the past. He sang \"[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGIndlf_xU4&t=64s Rebecca]\", [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QU462sGMclc \"GaNaDaRaMaBaSa\", \"Dance With Me Miss\"], and \"Fantasy\". Still slim in figure and soulful in his performance, he dazzled the audience and show hosts.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Yang Joon-il, a musician living ahead of his time, finally recognized 30 year later
column7: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> When asked his next plans amid this viral syndrome, he simply said: \"I don't make any plans; I just focus on fully living every moment. If there's any plans, I hope to live as a humble husband and dad.\" When the show hosts asked him to give a message to 20-year-old himself living 30 years ago, Yang said: \"I know nothing will happen how you want. But don't worry, everything will come out perfectly in the end.\"<ref name=\"koreatimes\" /> After his fame skyrocketed again after his appearance on the show, he quit his job at the restaurant to focus on his entertainment career.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title='G-Dragon of the 90s' Yang Joon Il visits JTBC's 'News Room' after his surging popularity, says he was working at a restaurant in Florida

column1: On December 25, Christmas Day, he appeared on [[JTBC Newsroom]]. He said \"It's like a dream every day\", \"I've been trying to get rid of my prejudice against myself, which is full of my mind as if I had to abandon my unhappiness before I was happy.\"  \"There are no more tears\" Yang said, adding that his powerful fandom, which claims to be a support group, is also a big boost to Yang.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Celebrity of celebrity, Yang Joon-il Syndrome in Korea {{!}} HaB Korea.net

column1: On December 31, Yang met with fans through two official fan meeting events. \"Are you really here to see me?\"he said, tearing up with joy. \"This is my first time. I didn't imagine any of this. I'm so grateful.\"<ref name=\":1\" />  In a press conference at a fan meeting, he revealed that his sole dream of becoming a K-pop star in his 20s was finally accomplished now, at age 50.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Return of long-forgotten singer Yang Joon-il brings middle-aged fans to music scene

column1: Just a few days before the fan meeting he shot a commercial with Lotte Home Shopping<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title='GD of the 90's Yang Joon Il lands a Lotte Home Shopping CF
column5: access-date=2020-03-17}}</ref> for the first time in his life. He spent that money to rent an apartment in Korea.<ref>{{Cite web
column7: title=‘해투4’ 양준일 “생애 첫 광고모델료 받아 韓아파트 보증금 마련”

column1: On January 3 in 2020, Yang created his account on [[Instagram]].[https://www.instagram.com/jiytime/?hl=ko jiytime] On the 4th, he performed his debut song \"Rebecca\" on [[MBC TV
column2: MBC]]'s \"[[Show! Music Core]]\" after 28 years after his debut.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=At 50, forgotten Korean-American singer compares to G-Dragon
column8: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> Yang appeared himself a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buy_iFyS8Hg fan video], a parody of his own 90's fashion style.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inogwFkBgY4 interview] JTBC's special feature <Sugar Man, Yang Joon-il, 91.19> aired on the 16th and 23rd. The title of the program is meant to commemorate his debut year, 1991 and 2019 when he was recovered.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=JTBC set to air a variety special focused on Yang Joon Il

column1: He is in the process of publishing a memoir, recalling his music career and his life from a one-time singer into an English teacher and then a restaurant server in the U.S. He also plans to re-arrange and re-record his old songs to release a repackaged album. After that, he hopes to release new songs.

county]] located in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Indiana]].  As of the 2010 census, the population was 27,636.<ref name=\"census-quickfacts\">{{cite web

column1: Wells County is included in the [[Fort Wayne Metropolitan Statistical Area]] and the [[Fort Wayne, Indiana
According to the 2010 census, the county has a total area of {{convert
Wells County was formed in 1837. It was named for Capt. [[William Wells (soldier)
column2: William A. Wells]], who was captured by [[Native Americans in the United States
column3: Native Americans]] as a young boy and adopted by the [[Miami tribe
column5: Little Turtle]]. He eventually became a scout for Gen. [[Anthony Wayne
column6: \"Mad Anthony\" Wayne]]. Capt. Wells was killed by [[Potawatomi]] allied with the British at the [[Battle of Fort Dearborn]] at the outbreak of the [[War of 1812]]. The Potawatomi ate Capt. Wells' heart to gain part of his courage.

column1: There was also an accident that occurred at the [[clock tower]] of the county courthouse.{{citation needed
column2: date=May 2017}} While either fixing or building the roof, a man fell to the grounds of Main Street. He landed on his legs, and he lived for about a week before dying. The force of the fall thrust his [[human pelvis
column3: pelvis]] into his [[rib cage]]. Had he fallen any other way, he would have died on the spot.

column9: °F}} was recorded in July 1980.  Average monthly precipitation ranged from {{convert

column1: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[recorder of deeds
column4: clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column5: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

column1: As of the [[2010 United States Census]], there were 27,636 people, 10,780 households, and 7,684 families residing in the county.<ref name=\"census-dp1\">{{cite web

column2: title=DP-1 Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Demographic Profile Data

column3: PD/sqmi}}. There were 11,659 housing units at an average density of {{convert

column2: title=Population, Housing Units, Area, and Density: 2010 - County

column1: }}</ref> The racial makeup of the county was 97.3% white, 0.4% Asian, 0.3% American Indian, 0.3% black or African American, 0.8% from other races, and 0.9% from two or more races. Those of Hispanic or Latino origin made up 2.0% of the population.<ref name=\"census-dp1\"/> In terms of ancestry, 38.4% were [[Germans

column2: title=DP02 SELECTED SOCIAL CHARACTERISTICS IN THE UNITED STATES – 2006-2010 American Community Survey 5-Year Estimates

column1: Of the 10,780 households, 33.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 58.1% were married couples living together, 8.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 28.7% were non-families, and 24.8% of all households were made up of individuals. The average household size was 2.52 and the average family size was 3.00. The median age was 40.2 years.<ref name=\"census-dp1\"/>

The median income for a household in the county was $47,697 and the median income for a family was $56,885. Males had a median income of $41,871 versus $30,031 for females. The per capita income for the county was $23,169. About 6.2% of families and 8.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 3.6% of those age 65 or over.<ref name=\"census-dp3\">{{cite web

column3: pelvis]] into his [[rib cage]]. Had he fallen any other way, he would have died on the spot.

column1: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[recorder of deeds
column4: clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column5: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

column1: Of the 10,780 households, 33.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 58.1% were married couples living together, 8.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 28.7% were non-families, and 24.8% of all households were made up of individuals. The average household size was 2.52 and the average family size was 3.00. The median age was 40.2 years.<ref name=\"census-dp1\"/>

The median income for a household in the county was $47,697 and the median income for a family was $56,885. Males had a median income of $41,871 versus $30,031 for females. The per capita income for the county was $23,169. About 6.2% of families and 8.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 3.6% of those age 65 or over.<ref name=\"census-dp3\">{{cite web
